title: eden project creator sir tim smit criticises cornish people
story: As the creator of the Eden Project, Sir Tim Smit has had a transformative effect on Cornwall, bringing worldwide attention, jobs and a much-needed economic boost.But no good turn goes unpunished, it seems, particularly in a county where outsiders like Dutch-born Sir Tim are insultingly labelled “grockles” by some natives.For 20 years, Sir Tim has bitten his tongue as critics have railed against change, but he has finally let rip with an extraordinary takedown of locals who obsess about their “mums’ pasties” and romanticise “good old days” that never existed.In an expletive-laden rant, Sir Tim, who grew up in Sussex, accused Cornish people of defining their lives “in terms of what you don’t like” and of attacking entrepreneurs like Rick Stein who had helped rejuvenate their county.He told The Reason Why podcast: “One of the problems in Cornwall is, if you say anything – if you’re not Cornish – and you say anything about it, they say you’re an arrogant so-and-so speaking for the Cornish.“You feel, and I don’t, but you feel like saying ‘well if you were a bit more f- - -ing articulate you could speak up for yourself but you haven’t’.“You’ve all got mums who made the best pasties in the world and it’s fantastic and it’s fabulous, and you talk about the good old days, and the good old days never were the good old days.“They’ve been bad for about 70 years – and they’ve been bad because of t- - - - - s like you.”Sir Tim, 67, opened the Eden Project in 2000 after transforming an old clay pit near St Austell into a unique world of interlinking domes housing exotic plants from around the world. It attracts more than a million visitors each year and is reported to have contributed more than £1billion to the Cornish economy.Not everyone has welcomed the influx of visitors and cash, but Sir Tim said it was time they came up with their own ideas for taking the county forward rather than simply directing anger at those who are doing it for them.“His foundation was the fishermen of Padstow and him being a chef of fish.“He is personally quite anxious about being seen as a spokesman for Cornwall because he knows you get bricks thrown at you for saying you speak for anybody here.”Malcolm Bell, chief executive of the tourism body Visit Cornwall, said: “I suppose my reaction is I am a bit offended. The Cornish people are wonderfully warm and welcoming. It is regrettable because we are a community, we are a proud community. We know there are some strong views that most of us maybe don’t agree with and it does polarise people.“My view very simply is if you can’t say anything nice, don’t say anything at all.”On Wednesday, Sir Tim apologised for the comments. In a statement, he said: “I’m sorry that some of the comments I made in the podcast have caused offence. “I hope that when people listen to the whole piece they will realise that I was speaking in the context of defending my friend Rick Stein and my strongest words were directed at people who seek to damn him for making Cornwall attractive to outsiders.“I wasn’t intending to comment on Cornish people as a whole, rather some of those who would tell you that the past was better than now when the truth is different it was not.“Cornwall has been my home for more than 30 years and I don’t want  a few harsh words on my part to damage the many friendships I’ve made in a place I love.  “My comments in the round are extremely pro-Cornwall and the rightness of anger at the neglect of this special place  - and an encouragement not to attack the wrong targets.”The podcast was hosted by Cornish actor and musician Seamus Carer, who said: “I’ve tried to make a balanced, nuanced piece of journalism about Cornwall, from the point of view of someone who grew up and still lives here. With that in mind, I’m extremely grateful to Tim for giving me his time and opinions.“I’m a big fan of empathy, so can see where Tim’s coming from whilst also understanding the anger that some listeners have voiced. It’s good to remember that Tim’s made big things happen in Cornwall, which many people have benefited from. He’s a canny businessman, with a confident style. He’s always been very supportive of my work and is a family friend.“However, I’m aware that some people feel distrust and animosity towards him, hence why he was such an important figure to interview. The overall aim of the podcast was to look at issues in contemporary Cornwall and to try to understand both sides of the argument. There’s no simple answer to any of it, but having dialogue and listening is certainly a good start. That’s all I tried to do.”More from NewsPolitics latest news: Britain should never seek &#39special relationship&#39 with EU, says Lord FrostEmmanuel Macron denies French withdrawal from Mali &#39a failure&#39Russia-Ukraine crisis: Invasion in &#39next several days&#39, says Joe BidenStorm Eunice could produce &#39sting jet&#39 like 1987 Great Storm ‘Look at the screen’, GP told blind patientMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: hms queen elizabeth inside aircraft carrier royal navy flagship
story: The yellow-helmeted flight deck officer leans into a 40-knot wind and raises a small green flag in his right hand. I crouch behind him, clutching my robust but battered high-def camera. A few feet away, a snarling F-35B Lightning Stealth Fighter, sleek as a shark and every bit as lethal, prepares to launch into the steel-grey skies of the eastern Mediterranean.On the bridge, the navigators steer directly into the wind. ‘Steady on designated flying course, one-one-zero,’ says the officer of the watch.  ‘Steady on one-one-zero, sir,’ confirms the helmsman.The F-35B needs plenty of headwind to get airborne. The aircraft has a run-up of only 350 feet to the curved ‘ski-jump’, from which it will make its final leap skywards. Inside the glass-encased flight control tower behind us, the vessel’s Commander Air, Ed Phillips, aka ‘Wings’, looks up and down the massive flight deck and, when satisfied all is clear, gives a short sharp order:All eyes turn to the green flag held aloft and rippling in the wind. Probably worth no more than a couple of quid, it is brought down to the ground with a dramatic flourish the signal for the F-35B, worth well over £100 million, to get airborne.I brace myself for the immense power about to be unleashed. I’ve witnessed this many times and know what to expect. It’ll be exhilarating, for sure, but also terrifying and probably painful. I’m determined to capture on film a spectacular close-up of a launch as near to the aircraft as possible, but the timing is critical and so far I’ve manifestly failed to pull it off.The searing blast from the rear jet nozzle has always blown me off my feet and sent me sprawling. I have the bruises and cuts to show for it and God knows how much skin I’ve now invested in the roughened, diamond-hard surface of the flight deck. But I still don’t have the footage I want. This time, two hefty sailors are ready to hold me down, or at least try to. My fear is that no amount of muscle power will be a match for the explosive thrust of what is essentially a horizontal rocket.The pilot releases the brakes and opens the throttle. The Pratt &amp Whitney afterburning, turbofan engine raises its pitch to a terrifying scream as the aircraft surges forward. I clench my teeth, tense my muscles and, with my heart pounding in my ears, bear hug the camera in a semi-stable position. But how long can I hold on? Four vice-like hands press down on my hunched shoulders.It’s June 2021 and I’ve joined the ship’s company of HMS Queen Elizabeth for her first operational deployment. We are some weeks into a seven-month voyage to the South China Sea, not on exercise but, locked, loaded and ready for action, should it become necessary.The new carrier and fleet flagship, together with eight escorts (destroyers, frigates, supply ships and a submarine) comprise Carrier Strike Group 21 (CSG21) – the most powerful naval force to leave the UK in a generation. Prior to our transit through the Suez Canal and the Red Sea, on our way to the Pacific and the disputed waters of the South China Sea, the ship has been launching waves of jets on Operation Shader – in support of land forces in the fight against Islamic State in Syria. But this has prompted a reaction from the Russians. They consider this part of the Med their own backyard and are intent on letting the QE and her escorts know they’re not welcome here. But the QE is the new dog on the block and she’s here to mark her own territory, not with a wag of the tail but a snarl.Today’s launch of the F-35s, therefore, is not to attack IS but to ward off Russian warplanes attempting to overfly us. Pilots, drawn from the Fleet Air Arm, RAF and US Marine Corps, have been scrambling all day, sometimes in rapid two-minute intervals, to intercept ‘red bandits’ and escort them away at a safe range.The Russians, apart from wanting to goad the Royal Navy, are desperate to get a closer look at the QE, the most advanced aircraft carrier in the world, and also test the Task Group’s reaction procedures – not only in the air but also on the surface, with their warships, and underwater with their submarines. The QE’s Anti-Submarine Warfare Merlin Mk2 helicopters from 820 Naval Air Squadron are on constant patrol in order to monitor subsurface incursions and react accordingly. Nobody has actually opened fire, but there’s a lot of posturing and tactical lip-curling. If this is the start of a new Cold War, nobody is in doubt that things could heat up very quickly. The QE’s magazines are bursting with bombs, bullets and missiles of all descriptions and capabilities, as you’d expect on a warship that is now Britain’s main conventional strategic deterrent.Commodore Steve Moorhouse, leading CSG21, knows that Britain’s potential adversaries, the Russians and Chinese, will prod and poke his Task Group at every opportunity. ‘They want to see what we’re made of,’ he freely admits. ‘And I’m happy to show them, but professionally, in a spirit of confidence, not confrontation.’ Moorhouse is a steely commander but also a diplomat by default. After all, HMS Queen Elizabeth, a chunk of British sovereign territory, is part warship, part floating embassy. As the embodiment of ‘Global Britain’, her charge is to deliver ‘power projection’ on behalf of the nation: on the one hand that means hard-edged, lethal warfare on the other it’s about soft, political persuasion through deterrence, as well as overt support for allies around the world.Friends and foes alike will be watching this deployment with keen interest and I’m here to capture it on film for a forthcoming BBC TV series. But this isn’t the first time I’ve filmed HMS Queen Elizabeth. That was back in 2009, when I witnessed Princess Anne cutting the ship’s first steel at Govan shipyard in Glasgow. This was not so much the birth of Britain’s biggest-ever warship – more like her conception – and I was struck by the enormity of the occasion.  Sir Jonathon Band, the First Sea Lord at the time, spoke with passion to the audience and assembled media. The Queen Elizabeth Class of aircraft carrier, comprising HMS Queen Elizabeth, with HMS Prince of Wales to follow, would, he explained, ‘provide Britain with the means to deliver air power from the sea, wherever and whenever required, and in a stronger and more decisive form than ever before’. They will also, he added, ‘be the centrepiece of Britain’s military capability for many years to come’.The construction of HMS Queen Elizabeth and her sister ship meant a complete reinvention of the Royal Navy but, despite Sir Jonathon’s upbeat messaging, it was to prove a painful and long-drawn-out process. Our active carriers at the time, Ark Royal, Illustrious and Invincible, were about to be axed in the 2010 Strategic Defence and Security Review and with them the Navy’s Harrier squadron – its entire naval fixed-wing capability. Already, naysayers and vocal critics were provoking a heated debate over the pros and cons of a carrier-centric Navy, and whether there’d be enough escort ships to protect the carriers while at sea or sufficient sailors to man them – each would be three times the size of the Invincible Class carriers.General Sir Peter Wall, former head of the British Army, described the decision to build the new carriers as no more than a ‘vanity project’ that ‘lacked credibility’ and which could be seen to have ‘skewed the UK’s conventional defence effort to a damaging degree’. Max Hastings, ever the provocateur, suggested the new warships represented delusions of grandeur for a Navy in decline. Other denigrators were quick to point out that a large carrier is a big target – especially for the new generation of hypersonic missiles that the Chinese call ‘carrier killers’.Russia inevitably chimed in with some of its own political trash talk: ‘Just make sure you keep your new carrier away from Moscow’s warships or they’ll send it to the bottom of the sea.’Military hardware is an emotive subject, especially in the context of huge capital expenditure that might otherwise be spent on housing, welfare or the NHS, but £6 billion for two vessels (albeit a near doubling of the original budget) is modest compared to the eye-watering price tag of USS Gerald R. Ford, an American super-carrier of similar proportions which cost more than $13 billion (and which, according to the Pentagon, ‘has yet to demonstrate it can effectively defend itself from anti-ship missiles and other threats’).The glossy brochure issued by a conglomerate of shipbuilders known as the Aircraft Carrier Alliance certainly suggested that Britain was getting its money’s worth. At 65,000 tonnes, HMS Queen Elizabeth and HMS Prince of Wales would not only be the biggest warships ever built for the Royal Navy, but also the most powerful and advanced in terms of military technology and stealth capabilities – especially when married eventually to the state-of-the-art F-35B Lightning jet fighter.The sales pitch for the super-carriers came with a staggering array of facts and figures. The ships, it claimed, would be so highly automated they’d require only ‘lean-manned’ crews – less than 1,000 per ship, without aircrew. That’s broadly one fifth the size of an American crew on a similar-sized ship. They’d each have a four-acre flight deck, the size of three and a half football fields, nine decks and a hangar big enough to fit two Type 23 frigates side by side. Each carrier would have two propellers weighing 33 tonnes – exerting the same thrust as 50 high-speed trains and producing a maximum speed in excess of 27 knots (31mph). The six engines (two mighty gas turbines and four diesels) would produce enough energy to power a city the size of Swindon the electrical cabling and wiring would stretch six times round the world the ship, weighing the same as 35,000 family cars, would carry enough fuel to take those cars to the moon and back a dozen times… and on it went.The statistics were mind-boggling, but one thing was for sure: the challenge of building the first of these ships – the nine-decked HMS Queen Elizabeth – manning her, taking her to sea and getting her battle-ready was going to be a compelling story, as I learnt while following her construction in seven shipyards around the UK, culminating in her final assembly at Rosyth in Fife, like some gargantuan Lego toy. But, engineering aside, I knew that her real story would reside in the sailors yet to arrive the men and women who would breathe life into the country’s first super-carrier.  Foremost among them was Jerry Kyd, the ship’s first seagoing captain. I encountered him on the day he arrived in Rosyth in May 2016, as he addressed a fledgling ship’s company of just 456 sailors standing in front of their ship, still an inert hulk without propellers and dead in the water.‘The world’s a frisky place at the moment,’ he said. ‘And we have to be ready to respond to threats which I think are coming sooner rather than later.’ Kyd glanced towards their future home, encased in scaffolding. ‘HMS Queen Elizabeth, as big and sophisticated as she might be, is really just a huge metal box, full of pipes, wires, gadgetry and computer terminals. She’s missing one vital ingredient…’ He paused dramatically. ‘Without the flesh, blood, muscle and hearts of you, my sailors, that ship is just a robot. You, not the ship, are the most important resource at my disposal.’It was nearly a year before the QE was ready for her first sea trials. As a ‘new build’, there were bound to be problems. On the eve of our departure for the North Sea, Captain Kyd warned that there would be emergencies: ‘We’ll have floods, we’ll have fires. And casualties too. That’s the nature of this business.’For the best part of two months the ship was put through her paces off the coast of Scotland, where I joined them. The first aircraft, a Merlin helicopter, was landed on the flight deck within four days as the ship’s company got used to their largely subterranean existence deep in the belly of the beast. I watched with amazement as the sailors, many of them straight out of training, transformed the massive grey hulk not only into a working warship but a home from home. The QE was fast becoming a vibrant floating city and, with 23 nations represented from across the Commonwealth, all human life was here. My first challenge, however, was to learn my way round a ship longer than the Houses of Parliament and taller than Nelson’s Column and so gigantic that it boasted five kilometres of passageways and 3,200 compartments.Apart from a serious issue with a cracked thrust block that held one of the drive shafts in place, all went as well as could be expected. As Jerry Kyd foretold, there were plenty of fires and floods as the ship was pushed to breaking point so that her technical and seagoing limits could be identified. There were ‘casualties’ too, but thankfully only minor ones – the worst being cracked teeth and broken fingers. Sea trials completed, we finally entered Portsmouth dockyard, the ship’s designated home port, and within months the QE was officially commissioned by the Queen.After a period of maintenance, the ship set off for the next vital stage of her trials off the eastern seaboard of the US. Within hours of leaving Portsmouth we became aware of an ominous presence – a Russian Federation frigate called Admiral Makarov had closed to within two miles of our position. A highly capable warship armed with Kalibr long-range cruise missiles, the Makarov was in transit from the Baltic to Sevastopol on the Black Sea. While officially permitted to route through the English Channel she had clearly erted her course to have a closer look at our ship.  A few days later, just before starting our transatlantic crossing, we were suddenly erted into the Irish Sea to help chase off a Russian submarine spotted in British territorial waters. There was an increasing concern, as there still is, that Russians could be sussing out British underwater power and communication cabling – an obvious target for a potential enemy.  The Russian sub made a run for it as soon as we got close. Even before the QE had become operational the writing was on the wall and it was written very clearly in Cyrillic script. A sign of things to come (and indeed I write this as the world tries to second-guess Russian designs on Ukraine).Following this brief ersion we progressed across the Atlantic and the next dramatic event I witnessed was the ship’s first-ever run ashore in a foreign port, which didn’t go entirely to plan. In Mayport, Florida, after a night of heavy drinking, four sailors from the QE and two from our escort frigate, HMS Monmouth, were arrested for a range of alcohol-related offences including jaywalking, fighting and resisting arrest. Despite making headlines on both sides of the Atlantic, the episode was soon forgotten and at least part of the blame was attached to overzealous policing.  Captain Kyd, a pragmatist, reckoned that a night in jail was punishment enough for sailors letting off steam. ‘The question we have to ask ourselves,’ Kyd told his commanders, ‘is what sort of sailor would we want to go to war with? The automaton who obeys every rule, plays it safe and never takes chances? Or the free spirit who pushes his luck and breaks the odd rule?’    Kyd quickly refocused on the job in hand – namely to see an F-35B Lightning jet land on the ship’s flight deck for the first time. Helicopters were one thing, but a fighter jet that lands vertically using immense downward thrust from its enormous engine was quite another. Commander Nathan Gray, the Navy’s top test pilot, was the first to attempt a landing. It went without a hitch, although many questions remained about safety margins before the flight deck and aircraft could be handed over to front-line combat pilots. Two months of continuous, painstaking testing in all weathers, including a full-blown hurricane, gradually provided the answers. Gray, despite a few near misses, was satisfied that he and his colleagues had done all they could to ready the ship and aircraft for action.  And so to the present. Here I am aboard the QE once again – no longer on sea trials, but busy arm-wrestling the Russians, and before long she’ll be playing cat-and-mouse with the Chinese in the South China Sea. This is the acid test, with much at stake. The Prime Minister has declared he wants the Royal Navy to be the most powerful and influential in Europe by the end of the decade. CSG21 is the first step to achieving that ambition and proving that the new aircraft carrier is no white elephant but an effective instrument of government as well as an iconic symbol of nation.  Great adventure beckons and, once again, all life is here – a much expanded ship’s company of 1,650 men and women. Yes, there are the aviators yes, there are the seafarers yes, there are the marine engineers. But there are so many others: stewards, chefs, medics, gunners, aircraft handlers, writers, warfare specialists, physical trainers and intelligence officers. There is even a specialist chocolatier and, maybe because of him, a dedicated dentist and dental hygienist.‘Bleeding frozen chips!’ shouts Ronnie Lambert, an Essex boy, born and bred. ‘They want 10 more boxes in the main galley and they’re all at the back of the frickin’ fridge.’‘Well, get in there and pull ’em out,’ laughs fellow storeman Aaron Mackin. ‘It’s yer bleedin’ job.’‘Well, I’m transferring to aviation! Them boys have it easy up there. All sunshine and sea.’    The F-35B, accelerating from a standing start, rattles my bones. The heavyset sailors push down hard on my prone body as I attempt to point the camera in the right direction. The sailors are now lying on top of me – the jet stream strikes and skittles us. I roll across the deck, trying to protect my camera. Did I capture the moment of take off? I will check as soon as I can. Lying on my back I look up to see five British F-35s close in on three Russian MiGs.There will be more Russian warplanes soon. They’ll keep coming, but at least we know one thing: we have chips to go with our fish tonight. Must be a Friday.More from NewsPolitics latest news: Britain should never seek &#39special relationship&#39 with EU, says Lord FrostEmmanuel Macron denies French withdrawal from Mali &#39a failure&#39Russia-Ukraine crisis: Invasion in &#39next several days&#39, says Joe BidenStorm Eunice could produce &#39sting jet&#39 like 1987 Great Storm ‘Look at the screen’, GP told blind patientMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: relocate england scots vote independence says head major defence
story: The head of a major defence firm has warned his company could relocate to England if Scots were to vote for independence.David Lockwood, the chief executive of Babcock, said its huge fabrication yard at Rosyth could move south within three years if the firm was made to feel unwelcome after a referendum.Unionists said the intervention showed that major employers would desert the country if Nicola Sturgeon delivers on her plan of winning a referendum next year.Mr Lockwood, speaking to The Courier after Boris Johnson visited Rosyth in Fife this week, said Babcock could “manage” the break up of the UK but suggested this could involve relocation.Almost 800 skilled engineers are employed at the site, one of the largest waterside manufacturing and repair facilities in the UK.“I think in reality there will be plenty of warning if the vote were in favour of independence,” Mr Lockwood said.“There would then be a negotiation period and at the end of the negotiation period there would be an implementation period. So I don’t think there is anything that we can’t manage as a company.”He added: “If we had to replicate this in England because we were told we weren’t welcome here – which I think would be a bad mistake for Scotland – but if that were the decision, we can replicate this in three years, and the time window of negotiations is longer than that. It’s not ideal but it is manageable.”SNP figures responded by insisting that Babcock would be welcome in an independent Scotland. However elements within the independence movement, including the Scottish Greens who are in a coalition government with the SNP, have condemned Scottish-based defence firms as “arms dealers who profit from delivering death, destruction and misery”.Ms Sturgeon has insisted she intends to hold a new vote on independence by next year, although there are major doubts over whether she will be able to deliver.However, Mr Lockwood also warned that the ongoing constitutional debate alone was putting firms off investing in Scotland.“I think if you are already here it is manageable,” he said. “But I think it is a slightly different question if you weren’t here, does it affect your decision?“I am aware of people who are … it is a question they ask when they are making a decision where to base themselves.”Douglas Chapman, the SNP MP for Dunfermline and West Fife, said he was “disappointed” with Mr Lockwood’s remarks. “As the local MP I have consistently supported Babcock and the Rosyth workforce,” he said. “They make a very valuable and significant contribution to our economy. “They operate and are welcomed in many independent countries globally. An independent Scotland will be no different.”Stewart McDonald, the SNP defence spokesman, said the firm was “not just welcome, but vital”.He added: “Babcock is not just an important employer, but would play a crucial role in an independent Scotland’s defence capability.”More from NewsPolitics latest news: Britain should never seek &#39special relationship&#39 with EU, says Lord FrostEmmanuel Macron denies French withdrawal from Mali &#39a failure&#39Russia-Ukraine crisis: Invasion in &#39next several days&#39, says Joe BidenStorm Eunice could produce &#39sting jet&#39 like 1987 Great Storm ‘Look at the screen’, GP told blind patientMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: labour party trying just little hard
story: First we had Keir Starmer, arch Remainer-in-Chief, the man who single-handedly reversed his own party’s commitment to respecting the outcome of the 2016 referendum, dismissing any suggestion that there might be a case for Britain rejoining the EU.Now his deputy, Angela Rayner, has suggested the police could “shoot terrorists and ask questions later”. In an interview carried on Matt Forde’s excellent political podcast, she channels her inner Tony Blair by coming down heavily on the side of ordinary people against thugs, advocating a radical harassment approach by the police: “I want you to beat down the door of the criminals and sort them out and antagonise them. That's what I say to my local police – three o'clock in the morning and antagonise them.”It's all very refreshing, New Labour circa 1995 stuff. But there’s something implausible about it all. When Blair, as Shadow Home Secretary, coined the phrase “Tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime”, it seemed very much in tune with what we knew of the man’s political philosophy at the time: impatient with the bleeding heart lefty liberals who had repeatedly driven the party over a cliff edge in their pursuit of “progressive” policies, only to alienate the same working class voters they had learned about at university.His subsequent initiatives, such as on-the-spot fines for anti-social behaviour and anti-social behaviour orders (Asbos), addressed local communities’ priorities without bothering too much with the chattering classes’ concerns for civil liberties. The same concerns they talked about endlessly at dinner parties in their nice, expensive homes in areas that weren’t subject to loutish behaviour.Rayner, having been brought up in a council estate and in relative poverty, is exactly the kind of politician who would normally be best placed to champion such an approach, all the alternatives having miserably failed to protect ordinary, decent, working people from the excesses of vandalism and harassment. But there’s a problem. There is a giant elephant in the room, and it answers to the name of Jeremy.For she was one of Corbyn’s most loyal lieutenants, having stepped up to serve in the shadow cabinet when everyone else resigned in protest at his leadership in June 2016. We must assume that she was one of the 40 loyalist MPs who supported him (as opposed to one of the 172 who opposed him) in that month’s vote of confidence.Is she really asking us to believe that these recently-expressed opinions are her real ones – opinions which she has kept secret these past few years and only now can be expressed sincerely?Quite aside from the (relatively unimportant) party politics aspect, there is the far more serious issue of civil liberties, which even Blair took more seriously than Rayner. The obvious example is that of Jean Charles de Menezes, the innocent Brazilian man shot and killed by anti-terrorist officers of the Met in 2005, supposedly on the basis that he looked a bit dodgy. That, it could be said, was an example of shooting now and asking questions later.If Rayner simply meant to endorse current police policy of shooting actual terrorists who are rampaging through the streets attacking civilians, then that’s something we can all get behind. But in that case her views perhaps need a touch of polish, an element of nuance, before they’re revealed to the wider world.The problem for Rayner and her party is that she may very well be expressing views that she has held for some time they may be sincerely held and thought through. Given her upbringing, it is entirely possible that she genuinely recognises the need to apply a tougher approach to community policing and to stop seeing assailants, vandals and general ne’er-do-wells as “victims” too.But in agreeing to serve a man who believed none of these things, in portraying herself as a hard-Left tribune of the people in whom Corbyn and his followers could place their trust, she threw away the chance to be listened to once that leader was no longer in post. She, together with Barry Gardiner, Rebecca Long-Bailey, Richard Burgon and many others, accepted fast-track promotion to the shadow cabinet when the opportunity presented itself (a sort of assisted places scheme for politicians), squandering any chance the party had to rid itself of Corbyn and his voter-repellent views.Perhaps we should be more patient with those who seek to reinvent themselves in office. Tony Benn did it, after all, albeit travelling in the opposite political direction to Rayner. But a consequence of that is that the public reserve the right to view her and her newfound orthodoxy with a degree of scepticism. If she plays her cards right, Angela Rayner has a long career ahead of her. She will need much of that time to convince others that this time, at last, she is being sincere.In the meantime, don’t expect Starmer, the former human rights lawyer and Director of Public Prosecutions, to appoint her as Shadow Home Secretary.More from NewsPolitics latest news: Britain should never seek &#39special relationship&#39 with EU, says Lord FrostEmmanuel Macron denies French withdrawal from Mali &#39a failure&#39Russia-Ukraine crisis: Invasion in &#39next several days&#39, says Joe BidenStorm Eunice could produce &#39sting jet&#39 like 1987 Great Storm ‘Look at the screen’, GP told blind patientMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: no vladimir putin hasnt humiliated west
story: Only in the fantasy world that is Vladimir Putin’s Russia could the Kremlin seriously believe that the military stand-off over Ukraine has resulted in a humiliating defeat for the West. Mr Putin has deliberately provoked the Ukraine crisis with the aim of forcing the West to make painful concessions, such as denying Kyiv the opportunity to join Nato or withdrawing its military hardware from Eastern and central Europe.Yet, while the willingness of some Western leaders to maintain a firm line has, at times, been open to question, one of the more refreshing outcomes of the crisis is that the Western alliance has held firm. While French President Emmanuel Macron has shown an alarming willingness to undermine Ukraine’s sovereignty, and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz seems willing to rule out any future possibility of Ukraine joining Nato, the bottom line remains that, to date, no meaningful concessions have been made to Mr Putin on either issue. Instead, the Western alliance continues to discuss ways of crippling the Russian economy if Mr Putin is foolhardy enough to activate his invasion plans, demonstrating a level of resolve that has caught many off guard.The refusal to budge on Nato’s right to choose which nations can and cannot apply to join has certainly placed Mr Putin in a quandary, and may well explain why Moscow’s much-vaunted march on Kyiv – which US intelligence agencies had predicted would most likely take place yesterday morning – has yet to materialise.With an estimated 130,000-strong Russian battle group still camped on the Ukrainian border, such an eventuality cannot be discounted, and British security officials, together with their counterparts in the US and Europe, remain convinced that the Russian leader’s ultimate goal is to achieve regime change in Ukraine through military force. None the less, following the Russian defence ministry’s decision to release videos earlier this week of heavy armour being redeployed to barracks, hopes are rising that all-out conflict may yet be averted.For Mr Putin, who has spent much of the past few months stoking the flames of his latest confrontation with the West, the prospect of the crisis being resolved without him achieving any of his stated goals will be hard to accept. The Kremlin’s frustration that events are not moving in the right direction certainly helps to explain Moscow’s almost hysterical reaction earlier this week when Washington’s predictions of a looming Russian invasion failed to materialise.“They were humiliated and defeated without a single shot,” boasted Russian foreign ministry spokesperson Maria Zakharova, adding that Russia’s failure to launch its invasion according to the CIA’s precise timetable “will go down in history as the day when Western war propaganda failed”.It still remains to be seen whether the West has badly misjudged Mr Putin’s intentions towards Ukraine, with the Biden administration continuing to warn that an invasion “remains distinctly possible”, and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky confirming that Kyiv has yet to detect any meaningful sign of a Russian withdrawal.Keeping everyone guessing is very much how Mr Putin likes to conduct business, so that not even trusted aides like Sergey Lavrov, his veteran foreign minister, can know with any certainty their leader’s next move. And if Mr Putin can keep his key Kremlin confidantes in the dark, then what chance do his Western adversaries have of ining his objectives?Yet, for all his mind games, Mr Putin’s prospects of achieving any tangible political gains from the Ukraine crisis grow more remote by the day, irrespective of the narrative the Kremlin’s “fake news” machine seeks to conjure up.The Russian leader will look weak and inept if he pulls back from a full-scale invasion without obtaining any guarantees from Nato on Ukraine, or winning concessions from the alliance on its future military dispositions in eastern Europe. Furthermore, his aggressive stance towards Ukraine has forged a new unity of purpose within the alliance that has been sadly lacking since the fiasco of last summer’s withdrawal from Afghanistan. Mr Putin’s bellicose conduct on Europe’s doorstep has resulted in a significant uplift in defence spending among many member states, while previously neutral states such as Sweden and Finland are now giving serious consideration to applying for membership.If, by contrast, Mr Putin does press ahead with the invasion, he is unlikely to achieve a clear-cut victory. There is, for example, a growing consensus within Western security circles that the Kremlin has seriously underestimated the likelihood of Ukrainians launching a long and bloody resistance campaign, one that could ultimately prove very costly for Moscow.So, far from achieving a humiliating defeat of the West, as the Kremlin propaganda machine would have us believe, it is Mr Putin who has most to lose, whether he decides to invade or not.More from NewsPolitics latest news: Britain should never seek &#39special relationship&#39 with EU, says Lord FrostEmmanuel Macron denies French withdrawal from Mali &#39a failure&#39Russia-Ukraine crisis: Invasion in &#39next several days&#39, says Joe BidenStorm Eunice could produce &#39sting jet&#39 like 1987 Great Storm ‘Look at the screen’, GP told blind patientMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: dwp universal credit sanctions soar
story: Exclusive: DWP Universal Credit sanctions soar to , a month in extremely worrying riseThe number of sanctions has shot from a few thousand a month to , - a similar proportion to before the pandemic - after the DWP brought back face-to-face Jobcentre appointments. And the worst could be yet to come" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Couple-with-girl-counting-budget.jpg" width"" "" More Brits are having their benefits sanctioned as the nation emerges from lockdownsImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByChaminda Jayanetti:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsThe number of benefit sanctions imposed on Universal Credit claimants has skyrocketed, rising elevenfold in just five months. The shocking rise comes as millions of people are hit by rising living costs, with energy bills, National Insurance and inflation all surging this Spring while benefits rise by only .%.Sanctions were suspended in the first Covid lockdown, and remained low at first after being restored in summer . But they have soared since the Department for Work and Pensionsbrought back face-to-face Jobcentre appointments last April, with people who miss a session having their benefits cut or stopped.The number of Universal Credit claimants with a sanction rose from , in June  to , in November , the most recent month available. Scroll down for the full figures and join the debate in the comments. Have you received an unfair sanction  Tell us on webnews@mirror. The total number of people sanctioned across the whole month will be higher than the official figures, as they are taken on a particular day each month. The data also excludes Universal Credit claimants who are not in ‘conditionality’ groups, such as severely disabled people.And Tory ministers are now introducing even tighter rules, with claimants facing a sanction after four weeksthey refuse a job outside their chosen field, which could push sanctions higher. Anti-austerity activist Charlotte Hughes warned it was “extremely worrying as we face a huge cost of living crisis putting energy and food prices up”. She added: “Sanctions are a cruel and unnecessary tool to use against those that are already poor and living in poverty. “Benefit sanctions ensure a person or a family are dragged further into poverty, making them have to choose whether they can eat or heat for the duration of their sanction.“Sanctioning claimants creates a never ending circle of poverty and does not encourage anyone to look for more work.” Dr David Webster of the University of Glasgow, who has researched the impact of sanctions for years, said: “The impact of a sanction often lasts a long time. “If it causes a crisis in the family, orit leads to somebody being evicted, the effects are pretty long-lasting. “Sanctions drive people further into debt, because obviously people can’t stop spending money altogether – they have to find something to eat and so on. “They have to keep spending money, somoney isn’t coming in they’re going to have to borrow it, and they get further in debt. “That has damaging effects on their mental health, because there’s all the anxiety and stress. And for a minority of people there’s obviously the question of potential eviction.”  The sharp rise comes even as the overall number of Universal Credit claimants has fallen with the reopening of the economy. DWP figures this week show .% of claimants were subject to a sanction in November, a similar proportion to before the pandemic. That is up from .% in October and .% in September. “If you look at the trend, there’s really virtually no slackening in the pace of increase in that percentage – it’s heading skywards,” said Dr Webster. The DWP’s recently announced Way to Work scheme will soon force claimants to look for jobs outside their chosen field after just four weeks on Universal Credit. A DWP spokesperson said: “With a record number of jobs available, it’s right that people who can work are encouraged to take up suitable roles through our Way to Work scheme. As well as being good for mental wellbeing, people are at least £, better off in full time work than on benefits. “People are only sanctionedthey fail, without good reason, to meet the conditions which they agreed to, and the latest data shows the sanctions rate remains below pre-pandemic levels.”Sanctions by month Figure is the number of people on the Universal Credit full service receiving a sanction on the second Thursday of each month. title: keir starmer hints labour could
story: Exclusive: Keir Starmer hints Labour could stand election candidate against Jeremy CorbynEx-Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has sat as an independent MP since being suspended by the party in October Labour leader Keir Starmer on the campaign trail Image: Rowan Grfiths   Daily MirrorByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Feb |comments Labour could stand a candidate against former party leader Jeremy Corbyn, Keir Starmer has signalled. The Labour leader said he was on a mission to prevent Labour being linked to anti-Semitism for good - and did not rule out putting forward a candidate in Mr Corbynaposs seat at the next election. Mr Corbyn was suspended from Labour in October  over his reaction to a damning report on handling of allegations of anti-Jewish hate within the partyaposs ranks.He has represented Islington North since  but he would have to stand as an independent candidatehe fails to regain the whip by the next election. Mr Starmer was pressed on his predecessoraposs future by the Mirror as he hit the campaign trail ahead of next monthaposs Birmingham Erdington by-election.  Asked how he planned to ensure Labour upheld the values he hoped to roll out across the country, Mr Starmer said: “I said I would tear anti-Semitism out of the party by the roots in my acceptance speech. “We have been doing that and we have made progress on it.”Pressed on whether that would include standing a Labour candidate in Mr Corbyn’s seat, Mr Starmer said: “Well, Jeremy Corbyn doesn’t have a Labour whip at the moment.“That’s the position he finds himself in, and it’s down to the response he made to the report on anti-Semitism.” It follows claims Mr Corbyn could be deselected by the party in his safe seat of Islington North, which he has held since .It is understood he plans to stand at the next general election, whether it is for Labour or as an independent candidate. Mr Starmer also promised he is taking allegations of Islamophobia as seriously as anti-Semitism. “There is absolutely no hierarchy here, he said. “We have to root out Islamophobia in just the same way as weaposd have to root out anti-Semitism. “And we do it with the same determination and energy. title: partygate official bid publish full
story: Partygate: Official bid to publish full Sue Gray report - including all  photosThe Lib Dems have tabled an Early Day Motion to force all accompanying evidence... including photographs from the Sue Gray Downing Street parties investigation to be releasedBoris Johnson has until tomorrow night tohis Partygate police questionnaire Image: REUTERSByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb |commentsMPs have launched a bid to force Boris Johnson to release Sue Gray’s entire Partygate report - including all  photos she saw as evidence. The Lib Dems have tabled an Early Day Motion to release “all accompanying evidence” on gatherings in Downing Street and Whitehall, “including photographs”.Top civil servant Sue Gray gathered around  images and passed them to police, who are investigating  Westminster parties during lockdown. However, sources have said she is not set to publish the images, which it’s thought could include CCTV stills, when she produces a second report. And this week it emerged the Cabinet Office Liaison Unit has asked the Met Police to confirm it will not publish photos either, as part of its investigation. The Lib Dem motion would use the mechanism of a “humble address” to order a “full, unreacted report of the Cabinet Office” investigation to be published.  The government would also have to give “a full list of the names of any elected officials, senior civil servants, and political appointees” who are fined by police.This comes after the police and government suggested anyone who is fined will not be named, with Brits having to rely on Boris Johnson naming himself.But it is only an Early Day Motion designed to voice opinions on issues of the day, without a House of Commons debate. Tory ministers are under no obligation to give it any debating time, let alone a formal vote, on the floor of Parliament.And it’s understood Labour is not ordering its MPs to sign the motion. Lib Dem leader Sir Ed Davey urged MPs to back the motion regardless. He said: “Boris Johnson can’t be trusted to admit whether he or any other Conservative ministers end up being fined by the police. “We’ve seen time and again that his instinct is to lie, blame others or cover up the truth.” No staff feared publishing the damning pictures could harm their reputations, according to the Times. The Mirror has learned one photo shows Boris Johnson holding a bottle of beer at his own birthday party and was taken by his official photographer.Boris Johnson has until tomorrow night tohis Met Police Partygate questionnaire. The Prime Minister was issued with the quiz last Friday - and given seven days to send back the completed form.  He has been consulting lawyers over his responses - and is expected to resist any attempts to oust himhe is slapped with a fine.London mayor Sadiq Khan said it would be inappropriate for him to lean on police and ask them to release photos of the Downing Street parties.He told LBC: Just think how inappropriate it would be for me, a Labour Mayor, getting involved in operational matters where a Conservative politician is being investigated. There are some countries around the world where the police do have their arms twisted in relation to operational issues. I think it is right in our system where I have got no influence in relation to whether the police do investigate Boris Johnson, what is published and so forth. I have always, as the Mayor, been cognisant of the importance of me understanding which side of the line I should be on. news politics russia-sends--more-troops-"Ukraine crisis: Armed Forces Minster gives harsh reality checkByDan BloomOnline Political EditorTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsThe UK and US have accused Russia of boosting its forces on the Ukrainian border by as many as , troops - despite claims it was withdrawing some soldiers. A US senior administration official last night blasted Russiaaposs claim it was withdrawing troops from the border with Ukraine. They received a lot of attention for that claim, both here and around the world. But we now know it was , the official said. The anonymous official said Russia has increased its troop presence along the Ukrainian border by as many as , troops, with many of them arriving as recently as Wednesday. No details or evidence were given of how the US knew this to be the case. But the , figure was today backed by UK Armed Forces minister James Heappey. He said Britain has not necessarily been able to very the , figure, but warned imagery overnight showed a new bridge and a large field hospital and he was very worried. “Troop movements towards the border continue”, Mr Heappey told the BBC. For all the talk about de-escalation in Moscow, I’m afraid what we’re seeing in the opposite and we’re very worried about it.  He added: “All of the conditions are set, and from the moment President Putin takes a decision, it is literally just a matter of minutes before military effect could be felt in Ukrainian cities. “That’s dferent however to inevitability. I have a gut feeling because I’m seeing what I’m seeing, and I don’t think you spend that amount of money in putting that number of troops and planes and ships into an area unless you mean it.But I have hope that a diplomatic process can succeed, because the consequences of that not being the case are that tens of thousands of people could die.” The UKaposs Lieutenant General Sir Jim Hockenhull, the Chief of Defence Intelligence, added: Contrary to their claims, Russia continues to build up military capabilities near Ukraine. This includes sightings of additional armoured vehicles, helicopters and a field hospital moving towards Ukraineaposs borders. Russia has the military mass in place to conduct an invasion of Ukraine. UK Foreign Secretary Liz Truss warned Moscow could drag out the crisis for months in an attempt to undermine Western unity.  Moscow denies it has any plans to invade, and Russiaaposs defence ministry said yesterday its forces were pulling back after exercises near Ukraine. It published video that it said showed forces leaving the Crimean peninsula. But Ms Truss said it was essential the UK and its allies not be lulled into a  sense of security, adding: In fact the Russian military build-up shows no signs of slowing. We must have no illusions that Russia could drag this out much longer in a brazen ploy to spend weeks more -not months - subverting Ukraine and challenging Western unity. This is a test of our mettle. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said in an interview on MSNBC on Wednesday that critical units were moving towards the border. On Tuesday, US President Joe Biden said the United States estimated that , Russian troops had encircled Ukraine, an increase from previous estimates of about ,. Russia had said that its forces - part of a huge buildup that has been accompanied by demands to the West for sweeping security guarantees - were pulling back after taking part in exercises in southern and western military districts near Ukraine.  But NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg said moving troops and tanks back and forth did not amount to proof of a pullout. Liz Truss will reaffirm support for Ukrainian sovereignty on a trip to Kyiv this week as part of efforts to deter a possible Russian invasion, urging Moscow to end its military buildup along the border. Truss will hold talks with Ukraineaposs Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba and will then deliver a speech in Kyiv where she will warn Russia it faces economic pain and global isolationit invades its former Soviet neighbour. In a speech in Kyiv, the Foreign Secretary will say the path of diplomacy remains openMoscow really does want a peaceful resolute to the crisis . We are ready to talk. But we are very clear -they decide to continue down the path of aggression, there will be massive consequences bringing Russia severe economic costs and pariah status, she will say. Following her visits to Ukraine and Poland, Ms Truss will travel on to attend the Munich Security Conference with other Nato foreign and defence ministers.  Russiaaposs deputy ambassador to the United Nations Dmitry Polyanskiy again dismissed the claims as fantasies by Western politicians. This is a very ridiculous situation, there has been hysteria, even hype, fanned for several weeks by our Western colleagues, he told ITVaposs Peston programme. They convinced each other and the whole world that Russia was about to invade, they were even naming concrete dates. So it happened in their minds, in their heads. Britain has already said it is doubling the number of troops in Estonia, with around  members of The Royal Welsh battlegroup heading from Sennelager in Germany and bases in Europe for the Baltic state, while  Royal Marine commandos are being despatched to Poland.  Four additional RAF Typhoon jets are heading to Cyprus to join Nato patrols over eastern Europe while offshore patrol vessel HMS Trent will shortly be joined in the eastern Mediterranean by HMS Diamond, a Type  destroyer. Meanwhile, so-called golden visas for wealthy foreign investors are expected to be scrapped by the Government amid concerns over links between Russia and the UK. Those eligible for the tier one investor visa, launched in , must have at least £ million in investment funds and have a UK bank account. It has been under review due to repeated concerns that the system could be exploited because not enough background checks are made on applicants. Sources confirmed the scheme will be abandoned in an announcement to be made next week. Lib Dem Foreign Affairs Spokesperson Layla Moran said: “The Conservatives have turned a blind eye to Russian interference in this country for years and had an open door policy to Kremlin cronies.“Cancelling the scheme is long overdue, it shouldnapost have taken the threat of a defeat in Parliament to finally get this Government to act.”Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON SoldiersUkraine crisis" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Exclusive: Dog with one leg gets adopted by woman who saved her from brink of deathTiny puppy Giselle was spotted on a traffic camera six days after being hit by a lorry and was left with only one leg, but Natalia George at Flori’s Friends Rescue in Kent couldn’t let her dieDisabled puppy Giselle has been adopted by the woman who saved her le Image: Floris Friends RescueByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Feb |comments A one-legged disabled dog has been adopted by the woman who saved her le. Natalia George, founder ofFlori’s Friends Rescuein Kent, rescued an -month-old puppy from the side of a road after a hit-and-run, and made the incredible decision to keep her.The German shepherd cross named Giselle was spotted by a traffic camera on the brink of death, and had to have two legs and one paw amputated. After an intense and gruelling  months, Natalia just couldnapost give her away - partly due to Giselleaposs complex needs and the incredible bond they both made. The amount of blood, sweat and tears we went through meant everything, Natalia said.  to ourTeamDogs newsletterfor your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.When Natalia first saved Giselle from the side of the road last February, her spine had broken and fused together. Floriaposs Friends Rescue “couldn’t save her mobility” and called her the charityaposs hardest challenge to date. Despite a dficult and long road ahead, there was no doubt in Natalia’s mind that she would do everything she could to help the puppy live. “I have a duty of care. My job is to keep injured animals safe,” she said. “Rehab was so intense and such hard work. The journey we went on together was just incredible.At first, Flori’s Friends Rescue planned on finding Giselle a home, but her needs became so high, “it wasn’t safe to rehome her”. “We care for a lot of paralysed and disabled dogs, but Giselle is on another scale,” Natalia said. Knowing Giselle would struggle to find a family that would fight for her, Natalia made the decision to adopt Giselle herself. Now, Giselle lives with Natalia at home and is the mascot of Flori’s Friends Rescue. “Evenshe had recovered dferently, I couldn’t give her away,” Natalia said.  Giselle now has a custom-made, four-wheel cart from America to help her run around, and a prosthetic leg from a specialist clinic in Oxford.She also has arthritis and incontinence - but none of that stops Giselle from enjoying le to the absolute fullest.Her favourite activity is chasing squirrels, and she spends two hours a day walking with her wheels. “Giselle had the will to live - there was no other way she’d have survived,” Natalia said. In total, Giselleaposs medical bills have exceeded £, in just one year - which is such a huge amount for a small charity.Natalia has set up a sponsor page for any supporters to donate what they can.Floriaposs Friends Rescue have many disabled dogs like Giselle that need a forever home - and Natalia simply cannot home them all herself.If you would like to give another dog a home, please visit their adoption page. title: brexit eu rules changes imports
story: Are you ready to import from the EU into the UK  Pasta firm has genius idea to helpAny business importing from the European Union into the UK must now be able to prove their meet the new rules of origin requirementsAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Feb Rules of origin are an important trading requirement. If you sell goods to the EU, or buy goods from the EU and bring them into the UK, you need to be able to prove that they meet the new rules of origin requirements to access preferential tarfs. It’s vital you understand the new rules to keep your business moving. To benefit from the preferential tarfs, you must have proof that any goods you import from the EU originate there, or any goods you export to the EU originate in the UK. Proof of origin can either be a statement of origin completed by the exporter, or evidence of the importer’s knowledge of where products originate. If you cannot prove the origin, you or your EU customer may be liable to pay the full rate of customs duty and could face penalties. Andrew Macleod, founder of London-based restaurant brand Emilia’s Crafted Pasta, explains that imports from the EU are vital to his brand: “We import ingredients directly from Italy, including special cured meats, cheeses, drinks and alcohol. Each of our suppliers is hand-picked.”  Has he had to make any changes to his business now that there are new import rules in place  “Yes – of course we already knew the origin of all the goods we import as we source everything carefully. But we’ve trained two of our managers on the rules around importing, so we know that we have staff in house who are well versed in the process.”  And having successfully navigated the changes, what advice would Andrew offer other businesses that import  “We found using a customs agent really helps the process run smoothly, but it’s equally important that you understand the rules yourself,” he says. “It’s not too late, and the gov.uk site has lots of valuable information.”  You must be able to prove the origin of any product you import You can choose to work with a freight forwarder or courier To benefit from preferential tarfs, you must be able to prove that any goods you import originated in the EU Note:you’re moving goods between Great Britain and Northern Ireland, rules of origin work dferently. Contact the Trader Support Service for up-to-date guidance and support. FIND OUT WHAT YOU NEED TO DO. Visit gov.uk rules-of-origin

title: britain become republic prince andrew
story: Britain will become a republicPrince Andrew s to public leKevin Maguire writes that Prince Andrews banishment from public le should be permanent after paying his sex abuse accuser a substantial sum to settle sordid charges he deniedQueen Elizabeth II and Prince Andrew on the balcony of Buckingham Palace during Trooping The Colour in  Image: Getty ImagesopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Feb If the royals permit the Duke of Shame to slime his way back on to the balcony there’ll be a revolution which turns Britain into a republic. Forever tainted Andrew’s banishment from public le must be permanent after paying his sex abuse accuser a substantial sum to settle sordid charges he denied. Because the court of public opinion will reach its own verdict on the U-turning prince now commending the bravery of a victim, Virginia Giuffre, his team disgracefully accused of lying in a stomach-churning smear campaign. And hoisting the white flag over Buckingham Palace to avoid a court inquisition means a man who until yesterday considered it honourable to be the guest of a convicted paedophile can never openly clear his name.  The donation to Giuffre’s charity combined with avow to campaign against sex trafficking and that apology indicate who won. She did. He still lost. The question remains unanswered about what to do with befouled Uncle Andrew despite relief in royal circles an Emily Maitlis mauling with knobs on is averted in a New York courtroom. Sneak him into platinum jubilee celebrations and the Queen will besmirch  years to rehabilitate a favourite son who’d be safer for the family locked in the Tower. Stripping him of a few courtesy titles and recognising the armed forces want nothing to do with Andrew isn’t enough.  The riot act must be read to him and a public declaration there is no way back nailed to the gates of Windsor Castle. Andrew remaining ninth in line to the throne and continuing to enjoy the perks of royalty is an insult to all women. It also goes to the heart of the rottenness of a hereditary monarchy, permanently elevating one family over millions of better others. Let her be Elizabeth the Last and vive la British democratic revolution. story: Emily Maitlis says Prince Andrews £m payout doesnt match with interview answersEmily Maitlis infamously interview Prince Andrew in what was almost universally called a car crash for the Duke where he claimed he couldnt sweat at one point and said he was "too honourable"The interview with Prince Andrew by Emily Maitlis of BBC Newsnight Image: BBC supplied by PixelByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Feb  Emily Maitlis has said that Prince Andrew’s settlement does not match up with the answers he gave her in their infamous BBC Newsnight interview.Yesterday, it was revealed this week the Duke of York had reached a settlement out of court with Virginia Giuffre after the sex abuse case against him. The Prince had long denied all claims against him, and during the interview, he even said he had never met Giuffre. However, he will reportedly pay a £million settlement after being ordered by the Queen and Prince Charles to sort the sex abuse case out. The terms of the deal prevent either side from discussing the case or the settlement itself in public - and the settlement is believed to have been made on the basis Prince Andrew makes no admission of liability and denies all allegations made against him.The total figure for the settlement will stand at more than £m, according to The .Writing on the BBC website, Emily Maitlis has said that the Duke’s settlement fails to match up with the answers he gave her. She said: “At the heart of the settlement is the biggest question of all: why is a prince who told me he had no recollection of ever meeting this lady now paying her what we understand to be upwards of £m  I distinctly remember putting Virginia Giuffreaposs accusations to him directly: aposShe says she met you in , she dined with you, danced with you, you bought her drinks in Tramp nightclub and she went on to have sex with you in a house in Belgravia.apos  “And I have the Princeaposs reply in front of me now. Three words only: ‘It didnapost happen.’” Because of this, she said there were only three possible explanations. “Either he was lying in that response - and remembered her well. “Or he genuinely had no recollection - and was adamant they hadnapost met - only for his memory subsequently to be jogged. “Or that he maintains his innocence, but feels the weight of legal and public opinion against him now make settling the easier option, albeit without accepting any liability.”She highlighted something the prince has come under increasing fire for, paying up such a vast amount of money to someone he was adamant he had not met. Maitlis also spoke about the preparation that went into the interview that she said would be “as forensic as any court document.” She added that she would be disappointed journalistically that “we won’t get to see how this story played out.” The veteran journalist does not stop there, she digs further into the Duke’s statement and points out the gulf between acknowledging Giuffre’s pain and any responsibility he may have for causing it. Throughout, she points out, the Duke does not acknowledge that they met. She goes on to highlight how Andrew backtracked, now regretting his friendship and closeness to Jeffrey Epstein. She wrote: “I asked him specicallyhe regretted the whole friendship with Epstein. And I remember my own inward gasp when he said: ‘No, still not... and the reason being that the people that I met and the opportunities that I was given to learn...were actually very useful.’  “In other words, that friendship was something he still valued two years ago. So why does he regret it now  Or does he only regret that it has become a source of such immense subsequent damage ” She added: “Youaposll remember perhaps that when I asked him why heaposd chosen to stay at the Manhattan home of a man whom he knew to be a convicted sex offender he told me he believed it was ‘the honourable and right thing to do’. “And then explained: ‘I admit my judgement was probably coloured by my tendency to be too honourable.’ A phrase that has in its own way become as legendary as the references to sweat and Pizza Express.” Read MoreRead More Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkPrince Charles, Prince of WalesBBCRoyal FamilyCrimeCar crashes" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Harry and Meghan may attend Charles’ coronation despite Duchess travel hesitanceAs Queen Elizabeth II celebrates  years on the throne thoughts are turning to what happens when Prince Charles ascends the throne and questions are being raised about whether Prince Harry and Meghan Markle will attend the coronationHarry and Meghan may feature in Charles’ coronation despite Meghan’s hesitance to travel Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByLucy WilliamsonReporter:,  Feb |comments Prince Harry and Meghan Markle may feature at Prince Charles’ coronation despite stepping back from royal duties, a royal commentator has claimed. With the Queen having reached the landmark of  years on the throne, attention is beginning to turn to what the future of the monarchy may look like once the Prince of Wales takes over.Previous reports suggested that Prince Charles intends to “slim down” the monarchy before his coronation and that only Prince William, Kate Middleton and their children would join him on the balcony when he becomes King. However, commentator Christine Ross told the Royally Us podcast that there might still be space for Harry and Meghan to be involved on coronation day.She said: Because of that historical moment where you have Charles, William and George, we’ll probably see them front and centre and their families front and centre. However, Christine added: “I do imagine that Charles will want a larger family group shot of the existing Royal Family.”The royal commentator explained that this might include wider family members such as Charles’ nieces and nephews – except Prince Andrew – and suggested this could allow Harry and Meghan a way in. “I do think that Harry would be a part of that and Meghan may be as wellshe wanted to be,” she noted. “I only say that because that’s such a public forum for her, and we know that she’s maybe hesitant to travel or to put herself in that situation again where the British press can speak about her in that way. “So I don’t think it would be so much about family feuds, as kind of indicating the future of the monarchy and also making everybody happy.”The Queen was surrounded by her family and maids of honour when she waved to huge crowds below the palace after her coronation in .A source told the Mail On Sunday that Charles wants his coronation to be far cheaper than the Queenaposs ceremony, which cost £.m - the equivalent of £m today.The plans for Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall’s coronation, which is due to happen within a year of his accession, are being discussed as part of Operation Golden Orb. Meghan and Harry abdicated their royal responsibilities in early  before moving to the UK to begin a new le in Los Angeles.  Other royals have taken on their royal duties - the Duchess of Cambridge recently took over Harry’s former role as patron of England’s Rugby Football Union. This comes as the Duchess of Sussex is yet to make a public appearance in  and was not present when Harry recently attended the Super Bowl with Princess Eugenie. title: healthy dad three said last
story: Healthy dad-of-three said last goodbye on -second call to family before Covid deathThe we of Des Louza, from Wolverhampton, who was married to him for almost  years, could only visit him in a hazmat suit once he was in a coma after contracting Covid a week beforeJodie Louza and her dad Des Louza, who said last goodbye on a -second call before his tragic Covid death Image: Jodie LouzaByAnnabal BagdiLucy WilliamsonReporter:,  Feb |comments A loving dad-of-three described as a picture of health has tragically died of coronavirus in hospital, having said his last goodbye during a -second phone call to his family. Des Louza, a technical engineer from Wolverhampton, had no previous health conditions but rapidly deteriorated just a week after contracting the virus, reports BirminghamLive. Coronavirus visiting restrictions in the hospital meant he could only speak to his family for just  seconds over the phone before he was rushed to a new ward and placed in a coma. The granddad of three spent the next five weeks fighting for his le but tragically died last March.Now, his daughter is now fundraising to help keep National Covid Memorial Wall a permanent fixture in London. His daughter Jodie Louza said: He must have been panicking. He was very weak and he just said bye and I think in his head he thought he wouldnapost get to say bye to us. We had a -second phone call with him. We could tell it was taking all his strength to say bye, thataposs all he could physically say. We were just distraught. You can’t really prepare for that - not being able to see him or be next to him. It was really tough. The -year-old added: My dad was the picture of health for his age.  You really donapost know how easily it could be you or someone you love. People should not forget that it’s still out there. The last text he sent to his daughter was I’m doing my best to fight this, Jodie recalled. Technical engineer Mr Louza worked for firm Atlas Copco throughout the pandemic until he fell ill with coronavirus in December . Jodie and her mum Kate, , looked after him for about a week at their Bilston home and both caught coronavirus themselves in the process.  But five weeks after being placed in the coma, the close-knit family were only able to visit him when medics called to say he was not going to make it. Jodie and mum Kate - who was married to Mr Louza for almost  years - went to the Covid ward, donning HAZMAT suits and helmets to say their final goodbyes. Her two heartbroken brothers stayed behind after becoming terried they would end up catching Covid for the first time. Jodie, a receptionist, said: They couldnapost understand why it affected him in the way that it did. They were hoping they could wake him up.  We couldnapost hold him and be normal. It was heartbreaking, really hard to digest. I was stubborn, I kept telling myself he will keep fighting. He was a fighter and a very strong man. I had never seen him ill before. He was very into his health and fitness. He was very humble. He was very fit. He had looked the same since he was , he did not age. It was such a shock. He was brilliant with his advice, he was loved. We would always have family game nights and he was really competitive and didn’t like to lose. He was an inspiration. I still canapost really comprehend it. It’s nearly been a year and I still donapost understand it. Jodie added the family are unsure where he contracted Covid, as he strictly followed the rules. It could have been something as simple as someone in the supermarket passing him. He really deteriorated rapidly, she added.Just three days after Mr Louza died, the devastated family received an NHS letter saying he was now eligible for the vaccine.Jodie added: It was unimaginable. I was very worried about Covid. I had a lot of people in my age bracket saying it wouldnapost be that bad. It’s the worst thing in the world. Unless you have been through this, it’s hard to realise how dficult it is. He didnapost have the funeral he should have had, it was really controlled and not what we would have wanted. Jodie is now planning on running the Carver Wolverhampton Half Marathon in April in memory of her cherished dad. She has already raised more than £ for The National Covid Memorial Wall - a London-based mural honouring those lost during the pandemic. She said: I think he would be proud. I would like to think he would be at the finish line. I needed something to motivate me, to work towards. I think it’s easy to get lost in grief. It makes me feel better knowing I am doing something in his memory and knowing it’s going to benefit other people because I know we are not the only ones who have been through this.To donate to the familyaposs fundraiser, visit Jodieaposs GoFundMe.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Coronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: it embarrassing royal family face
story: It is embarrassing for Royal Family to face scandals on Queens Platinum Jubilee yearThe reputation of the Royal Family has been tarnished by Prince Andrew’s court case. The Met Police also opened an investigation into claims Prince Charles’s charity offered honours to wealthy donorsThe Queen is celebrating her Platinum Jubilee this year Image: Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Feb This should have been a year of undimmed celebration for the Queen as the country marks her Platinum Jubilee. While the nation’s affection for Her Majesty remains undiminished, the reputation of the Royal Family has been tarnished by Prince Andrew’s unsavoury court case. To add to the Queen’s woes, the politan Police has opened an investigation into claims Prince Charles’s charity offered honours to wealthy donors. Clarence House insists Charles did not know what was happening at his foundation and is not involved in its day-to-day running. But the revelation is another blight on what should be a momentous year for the House of Windsor. For the Royal Family to be hit by one scandal is unfortunate but to be rocked by two in as many days is deeply embarrassing. The Queen described the year of  which saw the separation of Charles and Diana, the orce of Princess Anne and the fire at Windsor Castle as her annus horribilis. It would be deeply unfair on her Majestythe year in which she marks  years on the throne turns out to be equally grim.  Paying the price Soaring inflation is another blow to households hit by sky-high fuel bills. Prices are now outstripping wages and the recent increases in pensions and benefits. Rishi Sunak claims he understands the pressures on family finances. But he is still pressing ahead with a National Insurance rise this April. If the Chancellor genuinely cares about the cost of living crisis he would rethink this tax hike and help people more with heating bills. He should also send a clear signal to bosses that workers deserve a rise. Working people should not have to pay the price for this Government’s economic mismanagement.  Double trouble Forecasters warn that Storm Eunice could be the worst one in decades. Coming hot on the heels of Storm Dudley, there really is no calm before the storm.
