story: Man who couldnt figure out how to work Microsoft Teams wins disability claimDaniel Hayes was sacked for allegedly throwing a bag of poo and urine at a van - but he was forced to miss his own hearing because he couldnt work out the Microsoft Teams softwareDaniel Hayes has won a disability claim after he couldnt join his remote hearing because he couldnt figure out how to use Teams Image: Getty ImagesByTom Jackson:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA concierge who was sacked after he missed a disciplinary hearing because he couldnapost figure out how to work Microsoft Teams has won a disability claim.Daniel Hayes faced a remote misconduct hearing two weeks into the Covid- pandemic - but didnapost know what the popular video conferencing software was.When the hearing was rescheduled on Microsoft Teams a day later, the concierge at a luxury London apartment building again missed it and was annoyed it was not explained to him how to attend. Rendall  Rittner, which claims it is aposLondonaposs leading independent managing agentapos, held the hearing in his absence and he was sacked.  But now, Mr Hayes - who faced disciplinary proceedings for allegedly throwing a bag of poo and urine at a van - is in line to receive compensation after successfully suing the building management firm. An employment tribunal ruled Rendall  Rittner failed to make a reasonable adjustment by not reorganising the hearing for a third time by phone. Mr Hayes, who suffers anxiety, was left in extreme distress after twice not being able to access the Teams hearings, the tribunal heard. Mr Hayes, employed by Rendall  Rittner from April , worked at the Long and Waterson apartment building in Shoreditch, London. In February , contractors who Mr Hayes had animosity with complained to the company about an incident. A tribunal report said: Contractors complained...someone had put a bag on a contractoraposs vehicle which was said to contain excrement and was soaked in urine. [Rendall  Rittner property manager Ross Facta] looked at the CCTV and found footage of an item landing on the van. He then found footage of Mr Hayes throwing an item from the area known as the podium above the van. He also found footage showing him coming out of the staff room, walking through the foyer with something in his hand before going up to the podium. When investigated, Mr Hayes claimed he threw a tissue. He was called to a disciplinary hearing as the pandemic hit and was invited to attend a Microsoft Teams hearing on March , . The report said: [Rendall  Rittner] prepared a Microsoft Teams invitation whereby a hyperlink was sent by email.  This email did not give any instructions as to how to join. Microsoft Teams could be accessed via the internet by clicking the link. We accept Mr Hayes did not know what Microsoft Teams was, he did not have a camera on his desktop computer and could not connect. This was week two of the first pandemic lockdown. Many people did not know at that stage about Microsoft Teams and had not used it. After  minutes of waiting, an HR adviser rescheduled it. Another Teams link was sent to him, the report continued. [He was warned]he did not attend without reasonable cause or explanation then a decision may be taken in his absence. Mr Hayes did not attend. Mr Hayes did not try to find out about how to attend the disciplinary because he was both extremely anxious and because he was annoyed that the company had not given him an explanation of how to attend, it was heard. He said to the HR adviser aposhe did not know what Microsoft Teams was and asked her how she was so confident that he could use it at home. Mr Hayes expressed his anxiety was so bad he even had thoughts of taking his own le. Employment Judge Moor, sitting at the London East tribunal, said his anxiety was a factor in him not accessing Teams. Judge Moor said: We have concluded that there was a substantial dference between his ability to respond to the connection dficulties and a non-disabled personaposs. We have considered this with some care. It has not been an easy decision. It was a substantial dference because his extreme anxiety was very much part of the reason why he did not try to find an alternative way to attend the hearing on the day. A non-disabled person would not have had this additional mental obstacle. Judge Moor said Rendall  Rittner aposought to have knownapos his anxiety was a factor in him not contacting them about Teams and concluded they were unreasonable in proceeding in his absence and not rescheduling a third hearing by phone. Mr Hayes, who was sacked on April , , following the hearing in his absence, won a claim of failure to make reasonable adjustments for a disabled employee. Compensation will be determined at a later date. Mr Hayes lost other claims of unfair dismissal, harassment, and whistle-blowing. At the disciplinary hearing, Rendall  Rittner concluded Mr Hayes was guilty of misconduct for throwing the object from the building deliberately, but that Mr Hayes was not aiming at the bin lorry and it was not conclusive as to what was inside but that he could have urinated on it.The Samaritans is available  you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling  , email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. title: met office storm eunice map
story: Met Office Storm Eunice map: Exact areas hit by red alert and amber weather warningStorm Dudley has made landfall with heavy rainfall and strong winds in several parts of the UK, but Storm Eunice is set to bring even worse weather. Here are the exact areas affected by the stormStorm Eunice will hit the UK after a brief respite from Storm Dudley Image: Robert MelenByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Feb |comments After a short respite on Thursday, Brits will have to brace for winds reaching mph as Storm Eunice will move in causing signicant disruption for much of the UK. The Met Office urged Brits to stay indoors as much as possible as the storm looks set to make landfall on Friday, February .It has also issued danger to le amber warning covering almost the whole of England for tomorrow.Storm Eunice is expected to cause further outages and disruption to the transport network, after Storm Dudley left thousands without power and travel chaos in its wake.Here’s a map of the exact areas expected to be hit by Storm Eunice. Which areas will be affected by Storm Eunice  Met Office weather maps for Storm Eunice show a yellow weather warning for snow and wind stretching from just above Perth all the way down to Hull. It also covers the middle of England to capture York, Bradford and Sheffield.A stronger, amber warning is in place covering pretty much almost the rest of England. This amber warning for wind begins at am on Friday and lasts until pm. There is also a snow warning in force in northern areas from am until pm on the same day. The Met Office has upgraded to a rare red warning for southwest England including Bristol, along the coastline of Devon and Cornwall as well as the south coast of Wales. Previously, the whole of Wales was covered by an amber weather warning. The warning will be in place from am to pm, with the Met Office warning of potential danger to le. How dangerous will Storm Eunice be   After Storm Dudley, thousands of households were left without power across Northern Ireland and Scotland. These conditions are expected to continue into Friday with Storm Eunice which could be even more damaging, bringing stronger winds than Dudley, heavy snow and possible blizzard conditions. Forecasters have said that gales could reach up to mph in coastal regions and the Environment Agency has warned of the risk of flooding in southern England on Friday. Katharine Smith of the agency warned: Please remember to take extreme care on coastal paths and promenades. We urge people to stay safe on the coast and warn wave watchers against the unnecessary danger of taking aposstorm selfiesapos. Flooding of low-lying coastal roads is also possible and people should avoid driving through flood water as just cm of flowing water is enough to move your car.  People have already taken to social media to share images of fallen trees and howling winds as a result of Dudley. Train services were also disrupted by fallen trees, debris caught in overhead wires and the strong winds. The London North East Railwayare also advising people to avoid travel between London and the North on Friday as Storm Eunice hits. They also put out a statement on how their services will be affected :Our trains will be most impacted by the severe weather in the southern parts of our routeand as a result we will be running a reduced service between London Kingaposs Cross and York Leeds. We expect these trains to be extremely busy and subject to short notice cancellations and alterations. title: mum 40 writing children goodbye
story: Exclusive: Mum, , writing children goodbye notes after cancer treatment delayed in pandemicElaina Serghi, from Manchester, has written heartbreaking notes to her young children to read after her death - but believes things could have been very dferentElaina Serghi with her children Leo, , and Christina, , as desperate family members appeal for help Image: Elaina SerghiByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA mum told she has just months to live after her treatment was delayed says cancer patients have been left behind during the pandemic. Elaina Serghi, , has written heartbreaking notes to her young children to read after her death - but believes things could have been very dferent. Her family has turned to crowdfunding in the hope of accessing private treatment that can ensure she is there for children Leo, six, and Christina, three, for as long as possible. Latest figures show cancer treatment times have reached a record high as the government faces calls to deal with the huge backlog. Elaina, from Manchester, told The Mirror she had to wait for two months for a colonoscopy after falling ill in early , and an operation to remove a tumour was put back by more than a week.She was too ill to begin immediate chemotherapy after surgery and learned late last year that the disease, which started in her colon, had spread to her lungs and stomach. Elaina said: I want to be around for as long as I can, at my age I shouldnapost be writing notes for my kids to readI die, itaposs heartbreaking. I genuinely think it could have been dferent or at least not as bad. Elaina is among thousands who have turned to crowdfunding in the hope of extending her le, with more than £, raised toward private treatment after the disease spread. She said: Itaposs spread to my stomach now, Iaposm just hoping that new drugs will give me a bit longer with my family, thataposs all I can ask.  Itaposs really bad, cancer patients are being neglected. Itaposs not fair what weaposve gone through, Iaposve got two young children who need me.Elainaaposs family have launched a GoFundMe appeal to help pay for private healthcare and drugs to prolong her le.So far more than £, has been raised to support her. The moving appeal, set up by cousin Ana Papathomas, states: Heartbreaklingly, the chance to continue this fight has been taken from her. The only treatment which offers hope is not available on the NHS. It can only be obtained privately. Elainaaposs only way to keep fighting is to seek funding for this treatment. As you can imagine, this is not cheap and while it didnapost come easy for Elaina to take this decision and reach out for help, her single-minded desire to survive, to live, has left her with no other choice. Campaigners have called on the Government to prioritise dealing with the UKaposs huge cancer backlog, with more and more forced to turn to crowdfunding as the disease progressed. An estimated , people with suspected cancer will have to wait longer than two weeks to see an oncologist this year, Government analysis showed.And it is expected that more than , will not start treatment within the  or  day targets set by hospitals. Craig Russell, whose daughter Kelly Smith died aged just  in June  after her treatment was paused at the start of the pandemic, said more and more people are having to turn to crowdfunding.Craig, who set up the Catch up on Cancer campaign following Kellyaposs death, said: Iaposve heard far too many stories, there are lots of loved ones who have lost ones avoidably. Everyone is arguing about who is driving the fire engine, but the house is still burning down.He said the governmentaposs target to bring waiting times to pre-pandemic levels by next year simply isnapost good enough. Theyaposre saying itaposll take  months to get back to mediocrity, thataposs not the way we should be dealing with cancer patients, he said. He is haunted by the possibility that mum-of-one Kelly, from Macclesfield, could have lived longerher appointments had not stopped. There are questions over whether something could have been done, that makes it impossible to reconcile, Craig, , said. That question - have we been cheated out of six months, six years,  years - you just donapost know. The thought of other people going through this is heartbreaking. Minesh Patel, head of policy at Macmillan Cancer Support, said after figures were published last week: We know this will be having a devastating impact on many people with cancer who are experiencing agonising delays and risk a worse prognosis.In a statement the Department of Health and Social Care said: “Cancer diagnosis and treatment remains a top priority. The pandemic has put enormous pressures on the NHS, causing waiting lists to grow, but now most cancer services are back to or above pre-pandemic levels.“Our record investment in the NHS includes an extra £bn this year and £bn over the next three years to cut waiting times, including through delivering an extra  million checks, scans and operations, making sure more patients get the treatment they need sooner. “Last week the health and social care secretary declared a national war on cancer, with the launch of a call for evidence to inform a new -year plan to improve cancer care, speed up diagnosis and invest in innovative new treatments.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsCancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum accused staging house mould
story: Mum accused of staging house mould and pouring water down walls in re-homing bidAn electrician allegedly accused mum-of-one Chan Simpson from Plymouth, who claims her home is "freezing cold" and mouldy, of "drawing" the mould on the wall of her sons bedroom with penA Plymouth mum has said she was made to feel stupid and embarrassed after her housing company allegedly accused her of deliberately sabotaging her own home Image: Chan Simpson Plymouth LiveByElliot BallLucy WilliamsonReporter:,  Feb |comments A mum claims she was made to feel stupid after being accused by her housing association of staging a leak at her own home and drawing mould on the wall with a pen, in an attempt to be re-homed.Mum of one, Chan Simpson, from Plymouth, says she was accused of pouring water down her walls, after complaining since Christmas about a leaking roof and mouldy walls. A spokesperson for her housing company Plymouth Community Homessaid this was not the case and insisted they are working closely and sympathetically with her.The young mum, who moved into her home last May, claims her house is freezing cold after water began pouring in and claims sheaposs been electrocuted twice,  PlymouthLive reports.After an electrician inspected her home the shower blew which she says goes to prove that water is getting into the sockets.  She told PlymouthLive: Weaposve got water coming down the walls, itaposs freezing cold and weaposve got mould coming through in my little boyaposs room. We first noticed it around Christmas time because my grandad and grandma stayed with us and when my grandad got out of bed he put his hand on one of the walls and it was soaking wet. An electrician allegedly accused Chan of drawing the mould on the wall of her sonaposs bedroom with a pen. But Chan says the only action PCH has allegedly taken is to wipe the water away.  Carl Brazier, Director of Homes  Neighbourhoods said when PCH was first made aware of the issue alternative accommodation was arranged. He said: When we first became aware of the issues, we arranged alternative accommodation for Chantal and her son while we fully investigated the problems. Since then, we have carried out roof repairs and checked that the roof is not leaking, as well as adding extra insulation in the loft, all of which has remained dry. However, Chan claims after she contacted PCH a housing officer was sent out - but he was far from sympathetic to her situation and even accused her of spraying the water herself. She said: Theysent one of the housing officers out to have a look and he accused me of spraying the walls with water myself. My mum said, aposwho wakes up and thinks Iaposm going to water my walls today.apos Chan says most walls in her flat have been impacted by the leak and the accusation made her feel stupid and embarrassed, as well as upset that PCH had thought she would do this herself. Carl Brazier added: Chantal’s home has been visited by electricians, repairs supervisors, senior housing officers and contractors who have confirmed that the insulation above the fittings and fuse board is also dry, so we are still trying to determine where the water is coming from. “We are continuing to work with Chantal to find the cause of the problem, with our housing management and repairs teams having visited again early this week and we are committed to resolving the problem at the earliest opportunity. The PCH tenant says she believes the water entered a number of plug sockets making them unsafe, especially for a young child. The current condition of the home has become so bad Chan and her son have decided to move into her parentaposs house. She said: Theyaposve told me they will change the roof but they just wonapost tell me when because itaposs not an emergency. They donapost know where itaposs coming from so thataposs why theyaposre accusing me. Itaposs so wet weaposve had to come back to my mum and dadaposs house.  A spokesperson for Plymouth Community Homes, Carl Brazier, Director of Homes  Neighbourhoods said: “We have been working closely and sympathetically with Chantal and offering her support during this time so we can get to the bottom of the problems that she has been experiencing. “When we first became aware of the issues, we arranged alternative accommodation for Chantal and her son while we fully investigated the problems. Since then, we have carried out roof repairs and checked that the roof is not leaking, as well as adding extra insulation in the loft, all of which has remained dry. “Chantal’s home has been visited by electricians, repairs supervisors, senior housing officers and contractors who have confirmed that the insulation above the fittings and fuse board is also dry, so we are still trying to determine where the water is coming from. “We are continuing to work with Chantal to find the cause of the problem, with our housing management and repairs teams having visited again early this week and we are committed to resolving the problem at the earliest opportunity. news uk-news new-unseen-photo-queen-great-"Queen says she cant move as she holds in-person audienceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Feb |commentsThe Queen has shown off an adorable never-before-seen photo showing her surrounded by some of her great-grandchildren. The snap could be spotted in pictures released yesterday that showed her holding an in-person audience with military officials at Windsor Castle.The audience took place in the castleaposs Oak Room, Her Majestyaposs private sitting room, and the lovely framed photo could be seen on a table behind her. Itaposs unclear where exactly the photo was taken - but it appears to have been at her Scottish Highlands retreat of Balmoral. In it, the Queen can be seen sitting on a sofa surrounded by nine of her younger relatives. Standing behind the sofa and posing for the camera appears to be her granddaughter, Lady Louise Windsor, beside her great-grandchildren Prince George, Isla Phillips, Princess Charlotte and Savannah Phillips. Meanwhile sitting beside her on the sofa appear to be Prince Louis, Mia Tindall and Lena Tindall. Therefore itaposs likely the baby she is cradling on her knee is Lucas Tindall, who was born last March. Missing from the snap are the Queenaposs other great-grandchildren - Prince Harryaposs children Archie, Lilibet, August Brooksbank and Sienna Mapelli Mozzi. Another lovely picture also framed on the table shows the Queen and the late Prince Philip with their great-grandchildren at Balmoral in . It was taken by the Duchess of Cambridge and released by the Royal Family following the death of the Duke of Edinburgh in April.An extra-large Fortnum  Mason Milk  Dark Chocolate Selection Box, and a box of Bendicks Mint Collection – an assortment of dark mint chocolates - was also spotted on the same table.Meanwhile, during yesterdayaposs audience, where the Queen met with the incoming Defence Services Secretary Major General Eldon Millar and his predecessor Rear Admiral James Macleod, she admitted she was having trouble moving.  In footage of her audience, the monarch can be heard remarking loudly: “Oh. I’m here! I thought you might have just stayed in there for ages. Good morning.” Asked how she is, the smiling Queen, wearing a floral dress and holding a walking stick, points to her left leg or foot and responds: “Well as you can see I can’t move.” She is understood to have been feeling slightly stf, rather than having injured herself or being unwell. Later in the footage, Rear Admiral James Macleod remarks: “Well, many congratulations on the start of your Jubilee year”, with the Queen saying: “Oh thank you very much indeed.” Major General Eldon Millar adds: “She gave a little growl as we came in.” The Queen replies: “Oh really …she doesn’t normally growl.” Rear Admiral Macleod replies: “She obviously can see through us.”Yesterdayaposs audience was also the Queenaposs first in-person appearance since her Covid scare a week ago, suggesting she may have escaped the virus despite coming into contact with Prince Charles, who tested positive two days later.Buckingham Palace declined to comment. news uk-news prince-charles-harry-could-quizzed-"‘Cash-for-honours’ probe launched after Charles and ex-aide reported to policeByTom PettorCrime EditorRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb Prince Charles and Prince Harry could be quizzed as witnesses in a cash for honours investigation launched by Scotland Yard.The Prince of Wales and his former right-hand man Michael Fawcett were reported to police over a Saudi billionaire who made donations to royal charities, allegedly after he was promised a knighthood and British citizenship.In a move which could heap further misery on the Queen and Royal Family, the politan Police today announced it had launched a probe.The Prince of Wales, who presented Mahfouz Marei Mubarak bin Mahfouz with an honorary title at a private ceremony at Buckingham Palace in , has denied knowledge of the alleged deal.  The investigation emerged amid calls for transparency about Prince Andrew’s £million civil sex case settlement. The Mirror can reveal the Queen helped Prince Andrew settle the claim by making a £million donation to his sex abuse accuser’s charity. But ­questions were still being asked about whether public money was used. Her Majesty was today seen for the first time since her Covid scare last week, at an engagement at Windsor Castle. Standing with a walking stick, she pointed to her left leg or foot, and said: “Well, as you can see, I can’t move.” Tonight a source close to Charles confirmed the future king is willing to speak to police to help the investigation. They said: “There has been no request for help from the police so far, buthe is asked to help he will of course do so.” The allegations centre around ­businessman Mr Mahfouz donating £.million to restoration projects of particular interest to Prince Charles.  Mr Fawcett, who has since quit as chief executive of Charles’s charity, is alleged to have negotiated with fixers to secure a CBE for the Saudi who was said to be seeking recognition and residency in the UK infor financial contributions to The Prince’s Foundation. Prince Harry met Mr Mahfouz in  and was pictured shaking hands with the billionaire who donated £, to his charity.In December, the Sunday Times revealed that the pair met at a pub in Cha, West London, owned by Mark “Marko” Dyer, a former royal equerry known as Harry’s “second father”, who is said to have brokered the introduction in . They reportedly discussed Sentebale, a charity Harry set up after a gap year in Lesotho, Southern Africa. In response to the report, the Duke of Sussex issued a rare statement saying he had severed his ties with Mr Mahfouz. A spokeswoman for Prince Harry said: “The Duke and his advisers, as well as his nonprofit Sentebale, severed ties with Mr Mahfouz and his associates in , no longer accepting further donations to Sentebale and discontinuing any plans for a fundraising event amid growing concerns over his motives. “The Duke had one planned meeting with this donor nearly eight years ago, did not introduce him to any members of the Royal Family, and expressed concerns about the donor.”  Harry did not say what he believed Mahfouz’s motives were, or specy whether he shared his “concerns” with Charles or Clarence House. Despite the denials, former Met detective sergeant Steve Morris said: “Both Prince Charles and Prince Harry should be questioned without a doubt. “It is all part of the investigation, how the donor got to where he is within the charity, that is vital evidence to show the picture of how he has allegedly infiltrated the charity. “They should both be spoken to at the very least as witnesses. It would involve officers going to their address, or them being invited to a police station to give what’s called a Section  statement, purely as a witness at this moment in time.” Charles is president of the foundation but thought not to be involved with its governance or with trustees overseeing its day-to-day activities. A Clarence House spokesman said: “The Prince of Wales had no knowledge of the alleged offer of honours or British citizenship on the basis of donation to his charities.” Prince Harry could not be reached for comment. news uk-news strange-clouds-look-like-flying-"Storm Dudley : Clouds shaped like jellyfish fill the skyByShabir Noorzai:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsBizarre clouds that looked like flying jellyfish have left onlookers stunned as Storm Dudley battered the country. Brian Morrison, from Glasgow, Scotland, filmed the bulbous formation, which is known as Mammatus. The cloud formation is a rare and spectacular phenomenon which is the result of a process best described as reverse direction conviction.The clouds are an indicator of severe weather conditions.During a thunderstorm, warm moist updrafts rise to the top of the troposphere where the temperatures level off, creating the pendulous clouds. Brian filmed the video at around :pm yesterday in his hometown. Storm Dudley battered the country yesterday as strong winds and rain ripped trees from their roots and power outages in parts of the country. Winds speeds of up to mph were recorded in parts of the country with an Amber alert issued by the Met Office until midnight.As the clouds appeared, one local joked: Oh my God. Giant jellyfish aliens...Run! Another onlooker, Jen Edwards, said the clouds were “really cool to see, but also a bit creepy.  Another said: Ah man you were lucky to see those, I am slightly jealous. They often occur when thunderclouds form. Sue Smith joked: Sky dumplings. Storm Dudley saw ferocious winds of up to mph strike, as many were left without power in the worst affected regions as an amber weather warning was issued. This morning, yellow wind and ice warnings remain in place from the northern tip of Scotland to as far south as Birmingham.From Friday, Storm Eunice is predicted to batter the south and an amber weather warning is in place for the region, along with yellow warnings further north for wind and snow.There have been stark warnings that it could be one of the worst tempests in  years, with winds of up to mph possible in parts of the UK. title: teen couple nearly lose 16k
story: Teen couple nearly lose £, on dream home before mum rumbles fake landladyChristine Price was trying to find a rental home for her son and girlfriend who are expecting a baby, but was nearly scammed by a woman on Facebook posing as a landlordChristine caught the scammer Image: BPM MEDIAByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA mum is warning would-be tenants about a fake landlord scam after her teen son and his pregnant girlfriend were nearly conned out of £,. Christine Price had hoped a three-bed property in Stoke-on-Trent would be the perfect home as the young couple prepare to welcome a baby. But luckily the -year-old, who already has  grandchildren, realised something was fishy when she was asked for a £, aposdepositapos to be transferred upfront. It transpired the conwoman did not own the house in question at all.The fraud came about after mum-of-five Christine innocently posted on a Stoke-on-Trent Facebook page askinganyone knew of somewhere suitable.Stoke on Trent Live reports that she then received a message from a woman called claiming to be called Linda who said she had a house to let.aposLindaapos told Christine she lived in Canterbury and due to her aposbitter experienceapos of cancelled viewings she asked for the cash up front as security. She added thatthe house was not suitable, the money would be refunded in full.  Her ruse was rumbled when Christineaposs husband went to look at the property from the outside and noticed an estate agentaposs board. After calling the estate agentaposs Northwood, they confirmed they had never heard of aposLindaapos and the house already had a tenant. Warning others to be on their guard, Christine said: My bloodaposs boiling as so nearly got scammed. Iaposve been looking for a house for my son and his missus as theyaposre having a baby and want to live together. Theyaposve been saving for ages. Iaposd put a post on the Facebook page explaining what we were after.This woman claiming to be a landlady messaged me. At first I thought nothing was wrong but something told me in my gut that it wasnapost right. My hubby went to view the property from the outside and then called the estate agent whose board was still up. It turned out that they already had someone living there. The estate agent asked me the name of the supposed landlady and it wasnapost right. It was clearly a scam. When I called Linda out, she just told me I must have been at the wrong house and even said I wasnapost allowed to view her property without her there. Itaposs not against the law to suss a house out from the outside. The estate agent has been really good and got in touch with the real landlady. I also reported Linda on the Facebook page. She was expecting a deposit of £, which she probably would have gotI didnapost dig a bit deeper. This woman should be ashamed of herself. I just want to let other people looking to rent know that these scammers are out there andsomething doesnapost seem right, it probably isnapost. My son and his girlfriend had been saving for a long time to get the deposit together and they could have been back to square oneI hadnapost questioned it. A spokesperson for Northwoodaposs Stoke office urged prospective tenants to go through estate agents. They said: We are sorry to hear that the family almost fell victim to a scam, but are relieved to know that it was found out before any harm was done. The property in question had already been rented out, legitimately, by this office and our best advice to anyone looking to rent is to be extremely careful when using social media s and ideally always seek the guidance of a fully registered and accredited lettings agent such as Northwood to help you through the process. title: tesco praised inclusive card range
story: Tesco praised for inclusive card range that some shoppers say is long overdueSupermarket giants Tesco have been praised for releasing an inclusive range of Valentines Day cards with an added detail that many shoppers think is long overdueTescos inclusive move has been praised by shoppersImage: Getty ImagesByZahna EklundAudience writerRachel Pugh:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Valentineaposs Day has been and gone this year, but shoppers are still flooding one supermarket with praise for the range of cards they had on display earlier this week.Tesco customers have been rushing to social media to hail the shop for their inclusive Valentineaposs Day cards after spotting that several of them came with two messages written on the front - one in standard writing, and one in braille. According to the Manchester Evening News, one woman on Facebook said the cards were a great idea, and praised the supermarket for making braille cards - which are usually available from the Royal National Institute of Blind Peoplewebsite - more easily accessible.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Karen Davison wrote: What a great idea! Do they have braille birthday cards  I have a friend who is blind and this would be amazing. I know you can buy from RNIB online, but just asking. While Steph Laban loved the inclusive range, as she said: Love this. My daughter is fully blind and although she is only  at the moment, I love that she can now enjoy cards the way we do.There was also heaps of praise from Twitter users, including Simon Doherty who said Tescoaposs display was the first time heaposd ever seen braille cards.He noted: Fair play to Tesco, Iaposve never seen braille cards before.  Others called the push to sell accessible braille cards an amazing initiative, and said itaposs something that should have hit shelves years ago. The RNIB confirmed the range of cards the weekend before Valentineaposs Day, where they said they had teamed up with Tesco and Hallmark to design the cards with ied sensory features. They tweeted at the time: With Valentine’s Day just around the corner, @Tesco has worked with us to launch a range of cards for people with sight loss. The cards, created by @Hallmark, have ied sensory features on them, including dferent feel, texture and pattern work in addition to braille. The braille cards are part of Tescoaposs continued commitment to offering a more inclusive card selection across its stores. title: the queen always puts duty
story: The Queen always puts duty first, even after Royal Family rocked by scandalsAfter Prince Andrews court case scandal, Scotland Yard announced it is launching a criminal probe into an alleged cash for honours scandal at the heart of one of Prince Charles’s charitiesQueen Elizabeth II speaks during an audience at Windsor Castle Image: PAopinionByRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Feb Sex scandals, secret payoffs and police probes should be more at home in the latest Martina Cole novel than the daily lives of the Royal Family - and yet here we are. Just when The Firm thought they had buried one of the most shameful and humiliating periods in its recent history, the Queen has been dealt another hammer blow. Scotland Yard launching a criminal probe into an alleged cash for honours scandal at the heart of one of Prince Charles’s charities is not just another extraordinary development in exceptional times. It may call into question the very fabric of those operating at the heart of the monarchy.  Once again, as she has done many times before in times of trouble, the Queen today summoned the strength to put on a brave face and put duty first. But one could not fail to be moved by her admission, walking stick in hand, that she was unable to move as she would wish while a dignitary was wheeled out for a photo-op at her Windsor home. Just as she should be preparing to revel in the glory of her remarkable  years on the throne, it seems as though events are imploding around her. The family had hoped the shame of Prince Andrew’s involvement with two convicted sex offenders would be finalised ahead of Her Majesty’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations this year. But questions will surely remain over the Queen’s judgment in helping her son make such a settlement to his sex abuse accuser, which largely remains shrouded in secrecy. All of this against a backdrop of another potential scandal, which may see her son Charles and grandson Prince Harry quizzed by police, albeit as witnesses in the first instance. If ever there was a time to unite and collectively take the strain, now is that time for the family. Whether they are too fractured to do so is a story to be continued. title: thousands tar balls land uk
story: Thousands of tar balls land on UK beach after ,-litre oil spill in Irish SeaOil firm ENI UK has sent in teams to clean up the Blackpool beach after a pipe supplying fuel to the Isle of Man burst on Monday and now remains shut offPeople have been urged not to touch the balls or try to remove them Image: LB Photography   SWNSByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsThousands of black balls have washed up on a British beach just days after a broken pipe leaked , litres of oil into the Irish Sea. The small balls of tar were discovered on the coastline of seaside town Blackpool, Lancashire, sparking a major clean up operation. Their discovery comes after roughly  barrels of crude oil escaped from a pipe off the coast of North Wales, which supplies fuel to the Isle of Man. People have been urged not to touch the balls or attempt to remove them from the beach while clean up teams from oil firm ENI UK are sent in. A spokesman for the firm said: The clean-up teams are onsite and working closely with the local authorities and coastguard.  Pictures of the iconic beach have shown the small black balls strewn across the sand between the townaposs North and Central Piers. The burst pipe, which runs between two s named Conwy and Douglas, was shut off following the leak on Monday and remains closed. The coin-size pieces of tar are made up of a mixture of hydrocarbons and form when crude oil deposits are weathered after floating in the ocean. The local council said Storm Dudley is likely to see more balls wash up on the shore and has urged people not to touch or try to remove any of the balls. A spokesman for Blackpool Council said: Due to tidal conditions and a forecast of extreme weather conditions over the next few days, there is a possibility of more washing up.Our beaches will mostly be chained off due to high tides and storm force winds during this time, and we ask that people avoid these stretches to avoid any contact. Eni UK processes crude oil to produce fuels, lubricants and chemical products and is involved with offshore drilling in the UK. title: woman who fled abusive marriage
story: Exclusive: Woman who fled abusive marriage at risk of losing right to live and work in UKNadia is raising money to help pay the £, costs for an application to let her stay in the UK after losing her spousal visa when she fled her abusive marriageNadia, who is not using her real name to protect her identity, fled her abusive marriage in Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Feb A woman who was on a spousal visa and says she suffered psychological abuse at the hands of her ex-husband, driving her to contemplate suicide, is at risk of losing her right to live and work in the UK.Nadia, who is not using her real name to protect her identity, fled her abusive marriage and will be forced to leave the country unless her indefinite leave to remain application for victims of domestic violence, which is known as the SET, is approved by the Home Office.She is originally from Asia and moved to the UK as an adult. Nadia met her ex-husband through a dating app a year after moving. Nadia said she married who she thought was a “really amazing person” before she endured emotional and psychological abuse. Nadia told The Mirror: “I felt like I had found my person, we learned we had a lot of shared interests and had loads to talk about. We liked the same things. I fell into the relationship quite quickly and it felt so easy.  “We went on dates, I met some of his friends, and the people he worked with. There was no sort of red flags that started jumping out. We started living together after dating for two years and it was then that I started to see his behaviour change.” Nadia claims he coerced her into sex and allegedly convinced her she had mental health problems, causing her to spiral into a severe depression. Nadia said: “I had convinced myself that because he didn’t hit me or shove me or physically assault me that it wasn’t abuse. I didn’t know what he was doing was abusive and I later learned there are other kinds of abuse and manipulation. “He convinced me I was mentally ill and thatI had any issue with him or his actions he would put it back on me and that it was my fault.” She claims it took a while to recognise what was happening to her because things began to change at the start of the first lockdown - which is when everyone was more isolated than before. Nadia said: “While we were living together, I hadn’t realised it at the time but I was slowly becoming more and more isolated. It was sticky because this was the start of the pandemic so everyone was a little isolated and I just chalked it up to lockdown. “There was initially sexual abuse where he made me perform sexual acts without my consent and we had a conversation about it and it didn’t happen again in that explicit way.  “That became a problem in our relationship because he convinced me the problem was me and he guilted me, saying ‘ you love someone why wouldn’t you want to be intimate with them’. “I felt pressured to have sex and to be physically intimate with him and that had an impact on my emotional wellbeing. I became more anxious.” Nadia claims her ex would “emotionally punish her” by cutting off contact and disappearing for days on end. She said: “It felt like he was doing this to make me feel like I’ve done something wrong and then I would be the one to apologise and I would be worried to seehe’s okay. During one of his disappearances, Nadia says she contacted police and when they showed up they said they reportedly said they couldn’t determine a crime was committed. She said: “The questions were limited and there wasn’t room for me to explain how he used other forms of control that weren’t just ‘you can or cannot do this’. “The police officer said he didn’t have a choice but to not classy it as a crime and it just never went forward.” She added: “We started couples counselling because I thought there was a communication issue and I thought what was happening was normal and other couples were going through this.”  When the counselling didn’t help, Nadia says her mental health plummeted and she started to contemplate taking her own le. She said: “During one of his phases of disappearing he left me alone at home and I didn’t know where he went and I couldn’t contact him for days and that made me very anxious. “We had a lot of arguments once he got back in touch with me and then I just broke. I started spiralling and I was already severely depressed, it was quickly going from arguing to planning my suicide. “I think I knew I wasn’t going to go through with it because I reached out to my therapist. During that therapist intervention he said to me ‘I think you are in an abusive relationship’ and it took someone using that term with me to snap me out of it.” Nadia was able to leave the abusive household with the support of local services and that is where she learned about the SET. The SET is a pathway to remain in the country for iniduals who are currently living in the UK under a spousal visa but have to leave the relationship because of domestic violence.If you or anyone you know is experiencing domestic abuse, reach out for support – Womenaposs Aid’s live chat can be accessed  days a week via chat.womensaid.org.uk If the application is successful, the inidual will have indefinite leave to remain in the UK. If unsuccessful, the inidual must leave the country. There is no appeal process for this application. The moment Nadia left the relationship she violated her spousal visa, meaning she had to noty the Home Office explaining that she intended to apply for the SET. Nadia does not qualy for legal aid and her friend has set up a crowdfunding page to cover the £, costs of the y process. Nadia said: “The actual process is very dficult not just because of how much goes into the application because it requires me to find evidence for the abuse. That has been hard because I’m still coming to terms with the abuse and still trying to know what was the abuse.  “It is a financial burden, which is why we are raising money because the case is incredibly expensive to apply for the SET. “I needed to hire a lawyer and needed to pay for the additional psychological assessments. There is also the time it takes to liaise with the GP and medical professionals. It has been very exhausting both financially and emotionally. “By submitting the application I am telling the Home Office that I am no longer married and I am losing my spousal visa. If I am rejected I am no longer allowed to stay here. I’ve been told I could be given  days to leave but even in a situation where I’m mentally well that is just not enough time to relocate and reconfigure my entire le.” Nadia started collecting evidence and documentation for the application in summer  and officially submitted it to the Home Office with her legal team later in the year.One of the services that explained the legal process to Nadia was SouthallBlackSisters, a not-for-profit organisation that provides support to black and minority women experiencing violence and abuse.Shakila Taranum Maan, an Advocacy Services Manager at SBS, said: “We’ve been involved in a campaign for many years in terms of getting women who are spouses who come to the UK and are victims of abuse, and for the government to recognise that what has happened is not their fault. “If this provision wasn’t in place I think these women would have such an injustice in terms of representation. She added: “If the provision didn’t exist for those women, you would have to ask yourself what kind of justice system do you have. “We have rules and regulations in terms of domestic violence and they should be afforded the same support as UK nationals. “Women may not be aware that they can make an application and it’s really about getting that knowledge out there to women and victims of abuse so they can access that provision.” Nadia has been told it could take the Home Office up to a year to make a decision, and in her case, because the abuse was not physical it could be more dficult to determine. Simran Kaur, a Domestic Violence and Abuse Specialist Practitioner with the No Woman Turned Away project at Women’s Aid, said that abuse can be invisible, but doesn’t make it any less severe.She said: “It’s what people think of as abuse and what people see as abuse is still very much the problem, and there is this reliance on some sort of physical injury. “I think that belief stems fromyou don’t see it then it hasn’t happened. “What we often see is that survivors have struggled to come to terms with the emotional and psychological abuse themselves. Simran added: “That is why we have a lot of women approach our online chat and say ‘I think my partner might be abusive’. Simran said one way Women’s Aid supports women who face barriers to leaving - which can include a disability or immigration status - is through the No Woman Turned Away project. The project provides additional help to victimsapos local services so victims can be supported. Simran added: “It can take multiple attempts to leave and many women will come to us and say they tried but they donapost think they can. “Women need to know that evenone attempt fails that doesn’t mean your support ends there. “If a plan fails they might decide to try again later and we always encourage them to come back. Nadia hopes to hear the result of her application in the coming months and says knowing she had access to local services is what saved her. She said: “I am privileged to speak English fluently and have a higher education. I felt like I had the tools I needed to leave the relationship and to put together the case, which is incredible. I donapost knowa lot of women have the same access to those resources. “We need to invest in local community support, and we need to make sure that more women are empowered and have access to help.” A Home Office Spokesperson told The : “Domestic abuse is an abhorrent crime and we take the well-being of victims of domestic abuse extremely seriously, ensuring all evidence in their claims is carefully and sensitively considered. “No distinction is made between evidence of psychologicalabuse and physical abuse by decision-makers when assessinga person has been the victim of domestic abuse.” *If youaposre struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open   on  . title: first victorias secret model downs
story: First Victorias Secret model with Downs syndrome says her dreams have come truePuerto Rican model Sofia Jirau, who made her debut at New York Fashion Week, has called it a "dream come true" to become the first Victorias Secret model with Downs syndromeThe Puerto Rican model Sofia Jirau makes history as the first Victorias Secret model with Down syndrome Image: NewsflashByLee BullenJoe Smith:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A woman has celebrated making history by becoming the first model with Downaposs syndrome to pose for Vocitria’s Secret. Sofia Jirau, a -year-old Puerto Rican model and activist told followers she is taking part in the American lingerie brandaposs new Love Cloud campaign - advertising the collection of everyday underwear. Sofia’s career has been gathering steam since she made her catwalk debut at New York Fashion Week in February  and she has been attracting the attention of the fashion industry throughout the pandemic.She took to social media to share her delight at posing for Victoria’s Secret, calling it ‘a dream come true’ but some online commenters have raised concerns about sexualising people with Down’s syndrome, saying they had ‘mixed emotions’ about the campaign. Victoria’s Secret has launched a string of initiatives over the past few years to try and regain credibility in the face of declining sales and past accusations of a culture of misogyny at the business.Recent moves by the company include its first mastectomy bra, racially erse models promoting underwear in dferent skin tones, and hiring transgender beauty Valentina Sampaio after being criticised for its lack of ersity. Victoria’s Secret as previously branded a apostransphobic, fat phobic company that sets out to exclude most womenapos, by TV star Jameela Jamil while shop closures and the cancelling of its high-profile catwalk showcase have added to the companyaposs woes in recent years.Celebrating the news of her campaign today on Instagram, Sofia said: aposOne day I dreamed of it, I worked on it and today it is a dream come true. I can finally tell you my big secret… I am the first Victoriaaposs Secret model with Downaposs syndrome.aposSharing a black and white picture of her modelling the brandaposs bra, she continued: aposThanks to all of you for always supporting me in my projects. Thanks to @victoriassecret for seeing me as a #NoLimits model and making me part of the Love Cloud Collection inclusion campaign. This is just the beginning, now itaposs formed.apos aposInside and out there are no limits, Alavett,apos she said, quoting her own brand, which is named after the English phrase aposI love it.apos Sofia shared a black and white snap of herself wearing a floral balcony bra from the brand with her , followers. As well as modelling, she works as an activist with her No Limits campaign, called Sin Límites, which aims to raise awareness about Down’s Syndrome.  Sofia also founded her own brand, Alavett, launching its online store in . She came to global attention when she made her catwalk debut at New York Fashion Week in February . She said she hoped her success would inspire other people with Down’s. Speaking at the time she said: “I am proud as one of the few models with Downaposs syndrome who have managed to participate in the important fashion event. “Modelling in the United States was the beginning of conquering the dream I have had since an early age - to model on the most important runways in the world.”  Victoria’s Secret launched their Love Cloud collection on Monday designed to be comfortable everyday underwear as part of their ongoing efforts to rebrand. The campaign sees  women modelling the range, some are professional models while others are inspiring women, to reinforce the message that the brand is for everyone. The inclusive campaign features Celilo Miles, a Nez Perce Tribe-Wildland firefighter and Sylvia Buckler, an accessory designer who models the bra while cradling her pregnant belly. Speaking to Vogue, Celilo said she still cannot believe she was selected for the campaign. aposI used to watch the Victoriaaposs Secret fashion show and wish that I could be up on that stage. aposEveryone wanted to be in that club, but you knew you didn’t belong there, she said. She added that when she started modelling she tried to lose weight in order to fit a size she could not sustain because she believed it was the done thing. The campaign also features plus-sized models like Paloma Elsesser, and Devyn Garcia.Voguehas noted the collection is the first under the tenure of Victoriaaposs Secretaposs new creative director Raúl Martinez, who has been working hard at rethinking how the brand markets itself to women.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON New York Fashion WeekLingerieDowns syndrome" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: I took my mother-in-laws dog because it would be happier with meThe woman has expressed her guilt for taking the dog away from her mother and brother-in-law - but believes it would lead a better le with her because she has more to give" content"https:i-prod.dailyrecord incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JSjpg.jpg" width"" "" She feels guilty for taking her mother-in-laws dogImage: GettyByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Feb |commentsA woman has confessed to taking her mother-in-law’s dog because she thought it would be aposhappierapos living with her.Sharing her truth on Reddit, the woman explained how she’d travelled to her hometown with her boyfriend to spend time with their families.During their visit, they ended up checking in with his mum and -year-old brother on several occasions. The -year-old said: “His mother is married to a man who does a lot of drugs and is emotionally and has been physically abusive before.”Wanting to make up for his mistakes, the stepdad brought a dog home earlier this year - and the young boy bonded with it instantly. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. “They have a history of getting new dogs and the dogs accidentally running out the door and never coming back, she said.“This has happened at least three or four times.” It was during their visit when the woman asked her boyfriend’s mum whether she could take their new dog home with her, secretly wanting to ‘save’ it from suffering a similar fate to their other dogs. The woman added: “I thought she was very sweet and askedwe could take her. She needs to be fixed and get all of her vaccines and such. “Her husband was very hesitant at first but eventually agreed.  “The stepdad is rarely home now because he travels during the week for work, so the one who takes care of the dog is my mother-in-law and her son, who really loved the dog.” Without stating what her -year-old boyfriend thought about the situation, she revealed how guilty she felt taking the dog away from her boyfriend’s family. “We are on our way home and we have the dog in the backseat,” she said. “I am happy because I know we will be able to give her a better le away from the stepdad and also get her regular veterinary care. “But part of me feels really guilty for taking her.”Offering their opinion, one user said: “You know their situation, and you know how dficult it will be for them to give her reliable care. And, however reluctantly, they did agree to your request. You did not steal the dog. “Yes, it is sad for the -year-old. I’m sure he loves that dog -but he also likely loved all the other dogs that were abused, mistreated, or neglected. “At -years-old, he can’t have sole responsibility for an animal, especially under those circumstances. He can’t, for instance, take the dog to the vet as needed in an emergency. “I hope that when he gets older, he understands the situation better and thinks more that ’Hey, my sister-in-law and her husband were able to rescue a pet’. “Whether he comes to believe that or not, that is exactly what you did do. You know you rescued that dog. And your husband believes that too. “Animals don’t have to be in absolute cataclysmic situations to need rescue, and you made a decision that your house would be better, and safer, for this dog than your mother-in-law’s “If nothing , you signicantly decreased the likelihood of the dog running out and getting hit by a car. “Take a deep breath, let go of your guilt, and enjoy your new dog.” While another user said: “They have a history of not taking care of their dogs and you arenapost depriving them of the pooch - they can still visit when they come to see you. “Use it as a teaching moment to show your brother-in-law how to properly take care of a pet.”Do you have a dog story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AnimalsTeamDogsDogs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Sydney beaches shut after swimmer dies in first fatal shark attack in decadesSydney beaches including Bondi and Bronte have been closed as a precaution by Australian authorities as the hunt continues for the great white shark that killed a swimmer on WednesdayA Le Saver Rescue helicopter searched the water at Buchan Point in Malabar, off Little Bay Beach in Sydney Image: AAP PA ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA hunt is on for the great white shark that killed a swimmer in Australia with several beaches in Sydney now closed including Bondi and Bronte as a precaution on Thursday.The swimmer was mauled to death by a giant shark on Wednesday - the first such fatality at the cityaposs beaches in nearly  years.Drum lines, which are used to bait sharks, have been set up near the attack site while drones have been deployed as officials searchthe shark is still in the area.A video shared online showed a shark attacking a person on Wednesday afternoon off Little Bay beach, about  miles south of Australiaaposs largest city and near the entrance to Botany Bay.Police have not yet disclosed the identity of the swimmer.  This has been a complete shock for our community, said Dylan Parker, the mayor of Randwick Council which includes Little Bay. Our coastline is our back yard and to have a tragic death under such horrying circumstances is completely shocking. Local fishermen and beachgoers watched on helplessly as the predator mauled the victim to death. One witness told how they witnessed the shark swallow parts of his body after ripping what they believe to be a man in two. In the footage, those who heard the heartbreaking screams can be seen reacting to the devastating attack.  The attack comes days before the Murray Rose Malabar Magic Ocean Swim, an annual charity event usually attended by thousands of swimmers at a neighbouring beach. Organisers said they were monitoring the situation andthe event had to be postponed it would be held on March . A spokesperson for the New South Wales Department of Primary Industries said its shark biologists believe that a white shark at least  metresinwas likely responsible for the attack. It was the first fatal shark attack in Sydney since , data showed. Authorities have ordered people to remain out of the water on a hot summer day as temperatures hovered around C. A few crazy surfers still go out and take the risk but most of us take notice and just stay out of the water until the sharks have gone. Itaposs a lot more dangerous driving to be quite honest, said local resident Karen Romalis. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: proposed potato organisation sets out funding plans
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. title: lochgilphead composer creates new islay symphony
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThe Royal Scottish National Orchestra has recorded a new symphony written by a Lochgilphead composer who was inspired by the beauty of Islay.The Rinns of Islay, composed by Helen MacKinnon, is a -minute symphony that portrays #a musical journey around the Inner Hebridean island#, which was home to the composer’s grandparents and generations before.Inspired by stories of Islay in her youth, Helen began sketching the work during her composition studies at The University of Glasgow and ed to complete the work nearly  years later.The -minute piece for symphony orchestra was recorded in Glasgow Royal Concert Hall, with American-based PARMA Recordings and GRAMMY-winning producer Brad Michel.Helen, who grew up in Lochgilphead. explained: #It was a privilege to record with Scotland’s national orchestra.#The musicians and conductor, David Watkin, breathed glorious le into the work, which takes us on a musical journey around the island.#Due to Covid, we had a cross-Atlantic recording team, with technology connecting a producer in Boston with a team on the ground in Glasgow. It was a fascinating experience.#The new orchestral work was inspired by Islay’s stunning natural environment, known for its rich terrain and peaty whisky.Five short thematic movements celebrate Islay’s sunrises and coastal shores, while giving a playful nod to the island’s abundant whisky industry.Helen added: #The work centres around The Rinns – a beautul peninsula overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.#My father used to talk about The Rinns of Islay, and as a child, I started to create stories and soundscapes linked to the island.#The work offers a visual, almost cinematic listening experience, with atmospheres and landmarks inspiring the visual imagination.#The work features on a new album Legends and Light Vol. , featuring works by seven composers.While many of the pieces are arranged for orchestral ensembles, listeners will also find the Highland bagpipes and Irish Uilleann pipes featured on the album, offering a deeply rewarding listening experience.Helen is delighted with feedback so far: #I’m thrilled with audiences’ responses to the music.#Listeners have tuned in from across the UK, the USA and as far afield as New Zealand, keeping Scotland on the international map for new music.#
